author: {'steamid': '76561198028147978', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 58965, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 57234, 'last_played': 1710972967}
review:
Approaching 1000 hours of play time, it's about time I got around to writing a review for this game...

Basically, if you are a fan of wargames, more simulation oriented RTS games, and WW2 eastern front, you need to have this game in your library. This game offers an experience that no other game in it's genre offers.

The bread and butter of the game is the Operational Campaign mode where you fight a 1-4 day long operation on a map that can be as large as 100 square kilometres. You move battalion sized battle groups consisting of infantry, artillery, tanks, and other supporting units around the operational map in a turn based mode. When these battlegroups clash with each other, a Tactical Real Time battle is initialized in a 3x3km space on the operational map. 

Each map is handcrafted by the devs to recreate the real life battlefield. This means that the terrain you fight on is not crafted to be fair and balanced for good gameplay, what you fight on is just the real life locations. The environment is fully destructable - buildings will collapse, trees will fall, the ground is deform-able. Artillery will crater the ground, trenches are dug into the ground. Destroyed terrain and destroyed vehicles will remain permanently on the map, so if you fight another battle at the same location multiple times, you will see the destruction of previous battles. Since operations last for multiple days, you will be fighting in daylight conditions and nighttime conditions.  At night, your artillery will usually have access to illumination flares. 

The vehicles are all handcrafted with lots of little details that make them feel real. Damage is modeled in a very realistic way. Not all shell hits will inta kill a tank. Individual component damage and armor penetration are all modeled exceptionally well. When a track gets knocked off of a tank, you can actually visually see the track break off of the wheels. When the gas tank is ruptured you actually see the gas leaking out of the tank and sometimes catch fire. The level of detail here is just astounding.

The base game only includes one Operational map to play on, Stepanovka 1943, but the DLC will include operations going back to 1941-1943 in various locations along the eastern front. If you want to experience some more modern operations there are DLCs for the Angolan Civil war and the Iran Iraq war both set in the 80s using western and soviet made material like the T55, T62, Chieftan tanks. BMP, BTR, and M113 APCs. 

The game has some issues. The AI can be frustrating to control, but I think this just takes some getting used to. There are various mechanics that are not explained well / won't make much sense to new commers. This can be solved by either reading though the manual (included with the game files) or asking questions on the steam discussion form. You will usually get a good answer pretty quickly. The vanilla sound effects can be kind of flat but there are mods for sound effects out there, or you can modify them yourself pretty easily. People say that this game has a large learning curve - I think you need to go into this game having an open mind and a willingness to play around with things and learn how they work on their own. And always remember that the goal of the devs is to try and create a SIMULATION not necessarily a game. Be prepared to be placed into unfair situations were your only logical option is to retreat and regroup, and be prepared to totally obliterate the AI opponent when it gets placed into unfair situations as well. 

If you're craving operations that take place in WW2 western front, I would recommend buying Tank Warfare: Tunisia 1943. This separate game was made by the same developers and is essentially the same game with all the same mechanics just set in Tunisia with American and Commonwealth forces.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990397523', 'num_games_owned': 331, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 9689, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8636, 'last_played': 1688563690}
review:
Sans doute le meilleur jeu de stratégie temps réel sur le front de l'est à ce jour !

Le soucis du détails est présent absolument partout chaque opération est calquée sur son modèle historique de l'époque (d’après recherche d'archives historique y compris des journaux des unités en place) y comprenant notamment les noms des divisons/régiments et les dotations au moment précis de l'action bref vous revivez littéralement cette même opération au jour le jour ...

Attention cependant c'est un jeu plutôt complexe à maîtriser de pas ses nombreuses mécaniques allant de la simple ligne de vue et portée de voix pour donner un ordre jusqu'à la transmission radio et cohérence d'unités (chef de groupe proche de l'escouade pour maximiser l'effet de la communication), route de ravitaillement sur les cartes QG sans oublier les renforts à pourvoir suivant les régiments et les pertes en incluant également la staminas de vos hommes ainsi que leurs morales tout en passant à la consommation de munitions, d'essence ... ça semble être une usine à gaz si vous lisez cet avis mais au fond c'est très intuitif et une fois les bases maîtrisées il ne faut juste pas se lancer dessus en s'attendant à faire de la bataille assistée comme close combat ou Theatre of war ...

Que dire après ? Et bien encore une fois le soucis du détails en plus de la stratégie poussé permet de vraiment apprécier le titre !
Les modèles de dégâts sur les véhicules sont impressionnant tout peut y être détruit, phare, culasse de canon, embrayage, arme ... ! Simple exemple ; j'ai pu détruire en embuscade un char T-34/76 qui descendait une colline, le char a immédiatement pris feu suite à l'explosion mais l'inertie du véhicule ainsi que son pilote (mort au commande) a fait descendre le char en flamme en laissant toute une traînée d'essence enflammée sur le chemin pour finir dans les arbres en contre-bas et mettre le feu aux arbres autour ... c'est typiquement le genre de détail impressionnant pour un jeu de ce type mais ça ne s'arrête pas là, le terrain est déformable en temps réel (suivant le calibre des obus par exemple) et les stigmates de vos anciens combats (corps, épaves, incendies, destruction de bâtiments) resteront tout au long de l’opération ... sur les secteurs les plus acharnées vous serez amenés à combattre dans un no man's land total y figurant les traces de vos premiers jours de l'opération.
Autre détail sympathique les hommes peuvent se rendre ou un équipage abandonné son véhicule (dégâts trop important, tirs trop soutenu ...) si jamais le moral est trop bas et que les combats aux alentours dégénèrent ... une percée efficace est donc source de problème ou de victoire décisive suivant la situation.

Chose sympathique également lorsqu'une bataille se termine un tableau s'affiche y illustrant les résultats mais vous aurez l'opportunité de voir le champ de bataille mis en pause avec vos unités ou celle de l'ennemi (uniquement celle repérées au cours de la bataille) pour y voir notamment les tirs ayant ricochés ou ayant pénétrés sur un véhicule ... tout y est calculé également, la distance du tir, le type d'obus, son effet  ... les joueurs de l'ancienne simu de char "Steel Fury" sauront de quoi je parle.

Il reste quelques aspects à améliorer notamment l'IA ainsi que son pathfinding qui est parfois catastrophique avec un moteur physique assez étrange sur le terrain par moment, l'IA qui essaye par exemple de traverser une petite tranchée avec ses panzer IV et en perds 3 car ils se retournent ou un sdkfz qui a le malheur de rouler sur un rondin de bois et le fait se retourner ...

le petit studio Graviteam se concentre sur les batailles oubliées, n'attendez pas à voir du Stalingrad, Kursk, Berlin etc ... ici il s'agit de jouer les opérations qui se firent aux alentours et uniquement (pour le moment) de la période Août 1941 à Septembre 1943 et qui eurent autant d’impact mais que l'histoire délaissa ...

Bref si vous aimez la stratégie poussée et réaliste ainsi que le théâtre du front de l'est n'hésitez pas ! C’est un bijoux dans le genre et les DLC's ne sont pas anecdotiques en plus de soutenir une petit équipe qui mérite !

author: {'steamid': '76561197993823868', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 5273, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1222, 'last_played': 1688471331}
review:
Thankfully Graviteam has greatly improved the interface, otherwise this would be hard to recommend. If you're looking for a war game that's more of a simulator, this is definitely worth putting the time in to learn. I'm just scratching the surface at 20 hours played, but this is a deep tactical and operational level war simulation that I could see playing for years. 

It reminds me of Battlefront's "Combat Mission" series due to the way the battles play. However, this is better as it feels more true to life, and especially so with the added operational elements. Fantastic war game, really.

Prepare yourself to have patience learning the controls and interface. Do some tutorials and play around with with battle editor experimenting. It's worth it. And the community is great, so ask questions if you can't figure something out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006534458', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 8142, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8142, 'last_played': 1621081144}
review:
Feeling that ww2 strategy game ich? 

Loads up Company of Heroes 2; why does my Tiger have a max range of 100m? Why cant my mortars hit those troops, they are only a few hundred meters away. I need something closer to realism.

Loads up Steel division 2: why does my Tiger have 15 hitpoints, why does it have an armour rating value of 20 instead of the real life listed thickness in mm. Why does artillery do 5 health damage to tanks irrespective of how much armour they had in real life? Arbitrary values are annoying! 

Loads up Graviteam tactics; at last, my Tiger can shoot to its real life range of like 2km, and has real life armour thickness that wont take arbitrary damage from shells that could never penetrate its armour in the first place. Then Tiger gets stuck in the mud as i ordered it into a swamp, and is now stuck for the entire 2 hour battle. You get what you wish for: you want realism, you got it, just dont make tanks do something they werent designed to do, you will suffer the consequences (like i did).

author: {'steamid': '76561198003519449', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 17165, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13135, 'last_played': 1710208019}
review: An amazing interactive WW2 combat simulator. Packed to the brim with esoteric details, realistic to a fault. An extremely unique experience that has little in common with traditional RTS games. Forces you to play at a high level - giving general orders for companies or platoons to take hills and ridge lines (rather than trees and rocks). Micromanagement is definitely not emphasised unlike in most strategy games. You feel like you are interacting with multiple layers of autonomous agents that act on imperfect information and self-preservation instincts, which is surprisingly immersive and engaging once you develop an intuition for how the systems work.

author: {'steamid': '76561198380244511', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 44464, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 41783, 'last_played': 1710344341}
review:
-The game is in the present time in "early access. 50% completed.

-This means that soldiers can't carry mortars on their backs and will lose them in 100% game.

-The tanks target the enemy in front of them and then drive away. But they won't fire.

-The sound system in the game was 100% perfect. It is now replaced by an 8 bit sound card made of cheap sheet metal.
And I'm using DTS-licensed. Also licensed Dolby Access.

-Soldiers descend to the battlefield on a hang glider. Probably Otto Skorzeny. Although the game doesn't even include this feature.

-A machine gunner opens fire on his soldiers standing in front of him, wounding several.

Simulation of a soldier firing through an anti-tank trench. Even though he's inside the crater.
It's a scam on paying players.

They don't create any new animations or weapons or tanks. they just recycle the landscape and take money out of people's pockets to do the same.
Without any fix to the functionality of the game.

+ In contrast to Combat Mission you don't have to take care of each soldier individually.


https://postimg.cc/TK74djZn
This game has had the same unsolvable flaw for many years. After playing a few days on one map.
The game freezes and the whole map must be restarted from the beginning. This means 3 days of playing one map again.
In fact, they should do a protective save every 10 minutes.
Independent of yours.
Which would be indestructible.This way you only depend on one save and it is still broken for years.
This system doesn't allow you to jump out of a broken game. Instead, you have to repeat it all. At the same time, one battle lasts for three whole days.
As you can see in the photo, the game is broken again 15 minutes before the end.
There is no update today. It's just been playing still broken for years.
This defect has happened many times.


 Tactical information in 3D view is disabled when the camera height is low.
Worse and worse.Now you can't even see what orders you have with 1000 soldiers. Only a complete imbecile could put this in a simulator.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994017763', 'num_games_owned': 306, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 2350, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 777, 'last_played': 1705453913}
review:
*In progress review. Will update as I play more and learn more!*

Graviteam Tactics: Mius-Front is a one of a kind game. My friend introduced me to the Graviteam games as I wasn't familiar with them before. I will be sinking many many hours into this game over the coming weeks and months, and I want to tell you what I find so great about this game.

My favorite thing about Mius-Front that I think the game nails and gets so right is the tank and armored combat. Maybe it's just me, but many other games that portray tank combat are extremely arcadey or outright gimmicky. The combat just doesn't feel real. That is not the case with Mius-Front. Let me give an example: the Tiger Tank was an incredible piece of German engineering that had an impressive 100mm of frontal armor. Other tanks such as T-34s or Shermans just don't have the kind of penetrating power to get through that armor, they could hit the Tiger many many times and it would essentially bounce off of that armor.. just as it does in this game. However, if these other tanks get hit directly by the Tiger's 8.8cm cannon, they're almost always left a smoldering ruin. 

Another small detail but one I appreciate very much is the sound of the tanks tracks as they traverse the terrain. I have to (again) use the Tiger as an example. These tanks are hulks and the tracks leave a very distinct sound, one that I've heard on historical documentaries about the tanks. I'd say the developers got the sound of the tracks as close as you could hope for. All of the other equipment of an army can be used too; artillery, close air support, motorized infantry, and so on. But the tanks are the most satisfying in my opinion.

The battlefields are another important element of the game. Based on where you're battling, you may find plenty of places to lay an ambush or get ambushed yourself. The battlefield will change as the battle progresses. Things that are destroyed will stay on the battlefield for the whole battle. None of that disappearing after a minute or two nonsense. Tanks and other vehicles may blow up and catch on fire based on how they're hit. They might get stuck or malfunction and be out of action. All sorts of these things can happen, and it gives you the real visceral feeling of a battlefield. There is nothing more satisfying than seeing the destruction and burned out husks of vehicles littering the landscape after the battle's conclusion.

So far in-game most of my time has been spent in Skirmish and the Battle Editor. These are very fun modes to play around with to try out different strategies, units, equipment, etc. I haven't even gotten into the main meat of the game which is the Operations. Operations are basically a turn-based operational part (moving your units around on the map) followed by battles that actually take place once your and the enemy army engage. Definitely looking forward to those once I learn the game a bit better!

I think the aspect about the game that would be the most difficult to adjust or make sense of for most people would be the UI. There are a lot of buttons, each with their various functions and uses. But don't panic! That's what the battle editor and skirmish are for. A place for you to test everything out and see what works, and what doesn't. Honestly, you won't even be using all these buttons all the time. So don't sweat it. If you make mistakes, simply try a new tactic or do something differently until you figure it out. That's part of the fun! Don't give up on the UI and you'll be in for a real treat.

I recommend Mius-Front to anyone with an interest in WW2 simulations and battles, history, and TANKS!

author: {'steamid': '76561198067550454', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 343, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 191, 'last_played': 1697220205}
review:
This game is extremely complicated and I barely understand it enough to make truly insightful comments on it, but what I can say is that it's hands down one of THE most accurate combat simulation games ever created and it spares no minor detail in its representation of battlefields and warfare.

If that sounds like your kind of thing, as long as you can put up with a somewhat ugly UI and a total lack of included tutorials this game is basically a masterpiece that I cannot recommend enough. I also highly recommend their other games, be it the African Theatre version of this game (Tank Warfare Tunisia 1943), the OG Graviteam sims (1943 and Op Star) or their pretty solid tank sims.. Everything Graviteam does is a winner.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067163639', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 9992, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3892, 'last_played': 1706620611}
review:
I have been a gamer for about 20 years, and I never posted ANY review of ANY game ANYWHERE. Let that alone be a testimonial of how awesome a game it is :D This is really a gem and the best strategy/simulator about WW2 I ever played. 

Some pros:

- The uncertainty. You never know what AI will do, and it has its way to surprise you. I love this moment of tension at the beginning of the battle when you do not know where the enemy is and if you have made the right decisions.
- Graphics. I know that some people complain about it, but c'mon, it is a strategy made by a small studio. I think the graphics are really good.
- In my opinion absolutely brilliant decision is obligatory iron man mode. With it, you really got the feeling that your decisions matters and can have dire consequences. Many times I feel bad for my soldiers when I send them to certain death.
- It shows the chaos and dirtiness of war in kind of a beautiful way.

Cons:

- Of course, the UI, however, it's not totally bad, in my opinion. I had several moments when I clicked the wrong button and lost some unit or skipped a turn due to that.
- Lack of a solid tutorial to alleviate the learning curve a bit. It takes some time to learn the game but many times use of pure logic is enough. For example, if you send your troops head on to the enemy lines without the support, you cannot expect a positive outcome ;)

All in all, if you give it enough time and patience, you will probably have a great time with it. Just approach it with an open mind and do not play it like any other casual strategy game! If you play it like any other strategy game, you feel sorry very quick ;p

author: {'steamid': '76561197964662643', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 4028, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1494, 'last_played': 1688508840}
review:
Hallo zusammen!

Was ist Graviteam Tactics: Mius-Front eigentlich? Nun, es ist ein Spiel, oder eher schon eine Simulation, die Schlachten vorzugsweise im 2 Weltkrieg simuliert. Ein Spiel, was einen den Einstieg unglaublich schwer macht und man ohne gewisse Einarbeitungszeit, höchstwahrscheinlich keinen Spaß haben wird! Hat man einmal diese Hürde überwunden, so saugt einen dieses Spiel regelrecht ein! Hier stecken so viele unglaublich kleine Details im Hintergrund, die man, ohne diese Einarbeitung, niemals verstehen würde. Kleines Beispiel: Hier werden Kommandos, unter den einzelnen Truppführern auf dem Schlachtfeld simuliert, sprich, je näher sie sich stehen, desto besser können einzelne agieren, da sie sich besser hören!

Für den Einstieg, empfehle ich die Tutorials von "The WarSimmer" auf Youtube, leider auf englisch, aber trotzdem so unglaublich Lehrreich!

Aber was macht man nun? Wir spielen einzelne Szenarien des zweiten Weltkrieges nach, dafür benötigt man u.a die DLC.
Man kann jeweils Die Deutschen, oder auch die Sowjets spielen, je nach DLC auch mal andere Nationen. Man hat eine Übersichtskarte, in der man Truppen verschiebt, verarztet, repariert und aufmunitioniert. Es gilt darum Schlüsselpunkte, auf den originalgetreuen Karte zu erobern, wie ihr das macht, bleibt euch Überlassen. Prallen Truppen aufeinander, geht es aufs Schlachtfeld, sehr ähnlich, wie in der TotalWar-Reihe.

Wenn man auf die viele kleinen Mechaniken eingehen würde, würde der Text hier niemals fertig werden ;). 
Bevor ihr kauft, müsst ihr euch unbedingt im klaren sein, dass ihr eine lange Eingewöhnungszeit braucht, die Steuerung ist hakelig und nicht innovativ und nochmal, hat man diese überwunden, so wird Mius-Front zu einer fantastischen Kriegssimulation, die ihres gleichen sucht!

Der letzte Punkt: Der Sound, der oft ja eine Rolle spielt für die Immersion, wird hervorragend Simuliert, es kracht, es knallt, es explodiert. Es gibt auch Soundmods, die das Ganze nochmal auf einen höheren Level legen, einfach fantastisch!

Der Entwickler ist, soweit ich weiß Ukrainisch, wer also auf diese Art und Weise unterstützen möchte, dann durchs Gaming :). Klare Kaufempfehlung!

author: {'steamid': '76561198049984918', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1150, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 221, 'last_played': 1709851717}
review:
эта игра - деклассификация всех "реалистичных стратегий" созданных ранее. шедевр, с одним недостатком - странный, запутанный интерфейс игры, который сильно увеличивает порог вхождения. некоторые геймплейные элементы не понять без мануала, другие - вообще только если гуглить форумы. уверен, что  далеко не один игрок, купивший эту игру, бросал ее или делал возврат из за не интуитивности интерфейса и геймплея вообщем. особенно на оперативной карте. есть ощущение что интерфейс делал не дизайнер UI, а сами разработчики, реализуя "свое видение". это, как по мне, основная причина не большой популярности игры. но на данный момент(2022) конкурентов все равно нет - все игры схожих жанров(Theater of War, Man of War, Wargame series) сильно проигрывают по механике, как мерседес и запорожец....

*лично я играл в основном в Tank Warfare Tunisia, и мои впечатления основаны в основном на той игре, но так как это близнецы на одном движке, мой отзыв актуален и для Mius Front

author: {'steamid': '76561198346058406', 'num_games_owned': 186, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4652, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 11, 'playtime_at_review': 3323, 'last_played': 1711663557}
review:
The best WW2/Cold War battalion-level tactical simulator out there, period. 

As someone who spent hundreds of hours in the Combat Mission series of games, I was initially skeptical when first trying the game, only to be blown away by the simple elegance of the command system and quite competent tactical AI. An entire battle can be fought by issuing less than a dozen orders, and the tactical AI will be able to interpret your high level orders and conduct a sequence of sound maneuvers and fire missions to reasonably achieve what you intend to do.  For example, by issuing a single "attack" or "assault" command, you will see infantry gather into line formation, throw smokes, duck and return fire when fired at, and perform textbook fire-and-maneuver tactics when assaulting a defended position without you having to micromanage anything.

The operational layer of the game adds another level of replayability and nicely brings your tactical battles into context of the broader battlefield. As a commander your concerns not only lie with taking objectives and destroying the enemy, but also the preservation of your own forces, so that you are not overwhelmed later in a campaign. 

Another thing worthy of mention is the vehicular physics, it is simply the best out there for a tactical simulator. Module damage are realistically modelled and effects are adequately rendered to almost the same level as a game like War Thunder.

Only criticism is the opaque UI that takes ages to figure out, but it generally doesn't come too much in the way of enjoying the game. 

Overall an amazing game that I can see myself spending countless more hours into. 

But in the end, no tactical simulation can convey the horrors of real war, nor the grief of losing family, friends, and livelihoods. Many of the battlefields in this game are located in Eastern and Northern Ukraine whose real life locations are now again subjected to the brutal scourge of war from an invading foreign military. It is heartbreaking to witness history being repeated. The developers are based in Kharkiv, which at the time of writing is being subjected under brutal and indiscriminate shelling by forces of the Russian Federation. I know this won't mean much, but please keep the devs, their families, and the people of Ukraine in your thoughts. Here's to hoping that the studio may recover, and that the brave people of Ukraine stand strong and protect the peace and freedom they deserve. 

 Слава Україні.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027475064', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 5065, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 559, 'playtime_at_review': 2819, 'last_played': 1712451886}
review: A real beast of a war game and I still don't know if I like it or not.  Its both great and frustrating at the same time and has so many dichotomies in its performance. The pace is manageable, but too slow, the units are really easy to control, but really difficult to get the to do what you want sometimes, artillery is easy to call but super frustrating at the same time. I'll give it a thumbs up because I love the subject matter and you can have a lot of fun, but so many things could be simplified or abstracted at the same time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987292682', 'num_games_owned': 945, 'num_reviews': 320, 'playtime_forever': 2624, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 734, 'last_played': 1705648959}
review:
[h1]Amazingly deep and beautiful wargame[/h1]

One of the best wargame I've played, it resembles the Close Combat series in the way you give orders and the way it tries to portray realism. You have all the bells and whistles: a morale system, camouflage, a chain of command and communication lines that will impact on how fast the troops will respond to your orders. It even has a penetration system, so you can see what type of ammo destroyed your tank, and the direction of the shell. Really fully featured.

The game is also beautiful, the models are great, full of detail. Of course there are prettier games out there, but if you dig war machines you're going to be very satisfied.

This game also covers a bunch of war scenarios, the base game and most DLC are about WW2 south-eastern front, but there's also DLC of the war in Angola, the Iran-Iraq war, and 1960's borded clashes between the USSR and the PRC.

On the downside, this game series have a steep learning curve, it took me a couple of tries to "get it", and some scenarios can be overwhelming.

[b]For anyone interested, the game runs perfectly, no tweaks needed, on Linux via Proton[/b]

Lastly, I can't finish this review with out bringing up that Graviteam Tactics is a Kharkov (Ukraine) based studio, a city that is suffering today, as in the 1940's, the scourge of war. I wish all members of the Studio and their families are safe, and hope the conflict will end soon. Make wargames, not war.

author: {'steamid': '76561198170481929', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 18251, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 6, 'playtime_at_review': 9659, 'last_played': 1711813967}

author: {'steamid': '76561198017452947', 'num_games_owned': 222, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 1806, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 99, 'last_played': 1646571470}
review:
An absolutely amazing game, without a doubt the most detailed well simulated RTS ever made.
---
Devs, if you are reading this, I have one request for your consideration:

Make simplified version with similar levels of simulation, and ideally make it multiplayer. If you can do this, you'd bring a whole new audience to the game and it would be insanely fun to play this against someone I know. 

PS: I'd love to see a WW1 DLC at some point - and I wish the trenches you dig could be connected up in a long line rather than being separate. 

Besides that though, amazing stuff you earned yourself a new fan.

author: {'steamid': '76561198106099655', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 596, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 375, 'last_played': 1644006241}
review:
This Sim is in a league of it´s own. If you want to experience this beauty you have to work yourself in a few days via YT-content forum / manual (which is fun, cause the Sim is sooo OP).

After that you have a new world of Simgasm to enter. Graviteam Tactis graphic engine has been extra developed for it and it delivers very well performing and beautiful visuals with a top notch physics-engine, too. Nearly Everything which happens IRL is simulated and is sooo well thought.

OMG i have to leave now , the battlefield is waiting and i have to learn a lot.

Gravitem Tactics Mius Front ist der Hammer. Mein bester Kauf eines Strategiespiels ever. Die Sim hat sich auch kontinuierlich verbessert und ist jetzt ein wahnsinnig hübsches und extremst durchdachtes Game welches seines gleichen sucht. Es ist wie ein reeles Gefecht und die Entwickler sind offenbar wahre Genies. 

Einarbeitung ist natürlich nötig aber der Lohn unermesslich groß.

A (GOOD) SIM IS WORTH  A THOUSAND GAMES

Schaut mal rein und holt es Euch, damit solche Projekte auch in Zukunft dieses Level an Quali bieten können. So, muss zurück an die Front!

Hilfreiche Links:

Viel Spaß!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198065600557', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 227, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 227, 'last_played': 1643255994}
review:
I would like to preface this with saying that I don't generally voice my opinions in review online, but I feel that in light of the responses regarding an inquiry that I made in the community forum, a review for this game was warranted.  I have been playing WW2 games since the Close Combat series of the 1990s, as well as the original Combat Mission: Beyond Normandy, and Barbarossa to Berlin.  I absolutely love the era, and I love particularly seeing the Eastern Front represented, and enjoy playing it particularly from a Soviet Perspective....enough preface.

(highly abridged version)  I wrote a few paragraphs to explain my objections, thought the better of it, but it can be summed up in this.  The developer has no plans for late-war dlc, i'll be spending my money elsewhere in the future- why make DLCs for obsure South African Campaigns, Middle eastern conflicts in the '60s, and not late war WW2?  All the best to the devs, you can tell they love what they do.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040062168', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 2011, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 658, 'last_played': 1702125846}
review:
A ver como le ponemos al niño. Graviteam Tactics Mius Front... Bueno, como se le puede llamar Operation Star, o Tunisia, o incluso Blaze Armor. Porque sí, de Graviteam Tactics, hablamos de un pack indivisible, de juegos de incalculable valor -cualquiera-, tan amados como incomprendidos. 

Yo realmente empiezo en Mius Front, pero no por ello, no sé de lo que hablo. Jugador de Blaze armor y Operation Star, puedo deciros con franqueza, que pasa saber lo que hacemos y decimos con graviteam, si has jugado uno, has jugado todos. ¿Esto es negativo? Para nada. Cuatro títulos he mencionado, y comparten motor gráfico y mecánicas, a unos niveles de igualdad, que en pocos títulos y secuelas se dan. Y eso es un gran valor para mi. Por poner un ejemplo, los títulos de Combat Mission. Gustarán más o menos, pero todos sabemos que son un referente en cuanto a combate táctico se refiere. Lo que realmente aleja a mucha gente de la serie es su precio y su sistema modular. Te puede salir por un verdadero ojo de la cara, si eres como yo, un lo quiero todo. Pero, la gran ventaja, superada esa enorme inversión, es que no son gente de reinventarse a cada rato. No, la gente de Battlefront, están tan seguros de su producto, que simplemente lo actualizan y sacan nuevos módulos, sobre el mismo todo. Si te gusta y pasas por caja, desde luego no te van a sacar un refrito o una nueva versión, que deje ese gran desembolso en el polvo. 

Graviteam parece compartir esa filosofía, como comparte su trono en lo que se refiere a "mejores tácticos". Si tienes Operation Star, las sensaciones serán idénticas que con Mius Front, al igual que si tienes Tunisia. Blaze Armor es otra cosa, puesto que está enfocado en simulador de tanques, en primera persona (aún con el mismo aditivo de activos tácticos). Realmente las mejoras de que hablan con Mius Front sobre Operation Star -Tunisia comparte actualizaciones con Mius- son muy tenues y por debajo del capó. No sentirás que te tienes que reinventar y pasar de nuevo por la academia Frunze, para jugar el nuevo juego. Dos o tres horitas, un poco de intuición, y adelante. Por supuesto, eso siempre que vengas del pasado de Graviteam. Si vienes de cero, este juego tan maravilloso, te va a costar. 

Decía amado e incomprendido. Y ese es el gran defecto de Graviteam. Es un juego del este. Y en cosas como estas, te das cuenta de que realmente los occidentales, vamos a tener en todo, muchísima incomprensión al modo de caminar por la vida de las gentes del este. La interfaz de cualquier juego de Graviteam, para el estandar occidental, es absolutamente un despropósito. Pero una vez que respiras hondo, te das cuenta de que es simplemente diferente, y al poco, que puede ser tan inteligente e intuitiva como cualquier contraparte occidental, pero siempre que la enfoques como si fueras uno de ellos.  De hecho hay quien menciona que entre las "enormes" ventajas de Mius Front sobre Operation Star, es la nueva interfaz. Perdonen, es la misma, para el jugador nuevo es un infierno, y para el veterano, simplemente lo que estaba en una esquina, está en el desplegable del centro. Matiz arriba, matiz abajo, es lo mismo, con un poco de feedback. 

Entre otras del "este", está su desarrollador. Os recomiento encarecidamente que entreis en los foros que habla, aquí y en graviteam. Es más de lo mismo. Puro este. Yo realmente admiro lo seguro que está de sus estupendo proyecto, y como en un arrebato de desconocida sinceridad para un occidental, habla más claro que los obispos, y manda a paseo, o incluso recomienda no jugar a sus juegos, a clientes que no entiende, o considera malcriados. Desde luego unas lecciones de mercadotecnia no le vendrían mal, pero repetimos. Es del este, y allí no está tan claro lo de que el cliente cuando es un mimoso, siempre lleve la razón. Yo realmente admiro su sinceridad de bisturí. Y las risas van garantizadas con sus hachazos.

Puestos al corriente del pedestal, vamos a la estatua. Graviteam Mius Front es uno de los juegos imperdibles que todo amante de la táctica militar debe tener. Es un generador de batallas con el máximo ambiente que se puede representar de forma digital. Una batalla en cualquier Graviteam es toda una experiencia lujosa al detalle. Te sentirás muy bien ambientado. Sentirás la batalla, te dolerán hasta las pérdidas. Dicho esto, gran parte de la frustración inicial de este producto, es justo, no entender este producto. Esto no es STEEL DIVISION -estupendo juego, pero de otro rollo, otro ritmo-. Ni tampoco es el valiosísimo Combat Mission. Este juego es un simulador de batalla táctica en tiempo real pausable a gran escala en cuanto a dimensiones -sobre todo de mapa- se refiere. Realmente me aventuro a decir, que es el único juego a tiempo real, en el que eres consciente realmente de lo que ocurre. No llega al detalle del WEGO de Combat Mission y sus moviolas, que te darán la oportunidad hasta de ver como a un soldado le entra diarrea, pero tampoco será esos juegos de enviar a la picadora tropas, como si de la Batalla del Somme se tratara. Aquí se tarda en cubrir distancias de un modo real, se combate de forma espectacular en zonas cerradas y amplísimas, y más o menos, te puedes enterar con el tiempo cierto de una batalla. Sí, una batalla se asemeja más a Mius que a Steel División y su frenesí de clics. 

Es un juego realmente difícil de aprender, prácticamente de ir a la academia militar de wargameros. Cualquier cosa se puede realizar, pero tiene un coste en aprendizaje. Si quieres tirarte a jugar a "pelo", serás un comentario negativo. No por el juego, que sabes que es buenísimo, sino por siendo cabo, actuar de coronel, y no saber ni por donde te daba el aire. Leo de mucha frustración de jugadores, por que las "unidades no obedecen". Os juro, que este juego obedece, demasiado, pero el concepto del juego es TacAI y deficiencia de información; esto es, tu das un concepto de órdenes generales, y luego la IA las lleva a cabo como cree mejor, en la situación que se encuentre, y con la información que tenga desde sus ojos, ni mucho menos desde tu pedazo de vista de águila que ves todo el campo de batalla como ya hubiera querido Napoleón. Realmente, la guerra es así, y hasta Manstein a veces pisoteó su gorra, al ver que unas órdenes claras, un subordinado se las pasaba por el forro al no entenderlas. Tener eso presente. 

A mi a día de hoy, todavía me sorprende esta bestia infernal de la guerra que es Graviteam cualesquiera. Todavía me enseña cosas cada partida. Pero las satisfacciones que me otorga, pocos juegos lo producen. Cuando logras una buena cadena de mando y comunicación, y esta a su vez logra la tirada perfecta de artillería, y ves como machacas al enemigo en una sopa de acero explosivo, mientras a su vez lo flanqueas y pisoteas con tus tanques, y para remate a los restos desencajados de esas pobres gentes, les haces saltar del bosque tu infantería emboscada, es de las cosas más agradables del mundo y que te otorga un simple videojuego.

Realmente si eres wargamero, es impasable. pero tienes que concederte el tiempo que requiere. Un casual, jamás disfrutará. Pero cuando vayas comprendiendo, te sentiras que es un juego que vale cada céntimo. Y un verdadero comandante. La política de DLCs es brutal, pues alcanzar el sumum de Mius Front, se te va a ir a 200  pavos arriba. Y teng claro que si te gusta, realmente acabarás por pillarlos, aunque sean practicamente lo mismo, en otra fecha, con tre unidades nuevas. Las campañas operativas son realmente adictivas. Pero en otro giro inexplicable de los acontecimientos del mundo comercial del este, tienes a tu disposición siempre, Tunisia, a un precio que es de ganga. No me lo expliquen, pero Operation Star, que sería el abuelito, cuesta no menos de 130 leuros completo, pero tienen este Tunisia completo, a un precio normalmente de risa, para que te enganches, le pegues cientos de horas, te adicciones al Vodka, y vayas finalmente a Mius Front, y acabes pensando en ruso.

Maravilloso.

author: {'steamid': '76561198839158575', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 1390, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 839, 'last_played': 1648255411}
review: Absolutely dripping with atmosphere and detail and the best simulation / wargame I've seen that conveys the horror, terror and confusion amidst the slaughter that took place on the Eastern front WW2. The detail is incredible from tank platoons carving a path supported by Infantry, Artillery guns and Mortar units laying down barrages and individual soldiers seeking cover. There are a series of tutorials, but these only scratch the very basics of what the simulation offers, so be prepared to have to invest time grasping the systems where you can model battles custom / real and campaigns fought over a series of days. The night battles are spectacular with tracer fire lighting briefly areas of the sky along with explosions from shells impacting the terrain. Upon the conclusion of a battle there's a full breakdown of gains / losses and wealth of detail down to where rounds struck vehicles and the damage caused. Requires a high time investment to learn how your force works together to achieve it's mission, although there is a encyclopedia of all units within the game. Well worth the time as there's nothing to touch this.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972722445', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 10614, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10501, 'last_played': 1655006301}
review:
Best combined arms simulator I have ever seen.
Anyone interested in the  Eastern Front owes it to themselves to get this.
I almost gave up on the learning process to master this simulator but i am so glad i didn't.
Well worth the time invested in learning the game system once I mastered it. Best for people who love realism and attention to detail and are willing to go through an extensive learning process.
It is truly a simulator and not a game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042471289', 'num_games_owned': 933, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 726, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 379, 'last_played': 1689096991}
review:
[h1]Dreaming of a Game[/h1]

In most RTS, units work like so: You have some of them on a field, and you right click where you want them to go. They do so instantly. They can take hundreds of orders a second, and they engage targets you right click immediately and with no delay. 

When I was younger, one of my favourite pastimes was playing Lock On: Modern Air Combat. But it wasn't flying it, no. I had no HOTAS and the sim was too complex to play with a keyboard. Instead, I spent vast sums of time making engagements in the editor. Plonking tanks down, moving them about, letting them shoot at each other, putting in trigger zones, and so on. There's something unique and extremely fun about watching vehicles blow each other to kingdom come. The spectacle of war was something I was really drawn to. 

Ever since, I've wanted a strategy game like that. A game where you co-ordinate units on a large scale but let the intellect of the commanders and soldiers take over on a small scale. And I wanted a game where soldiers don't have microtransmitters up their bums at all times. 

Enter: Graviteam Tactics

[h1]What is it?[/h1]

Graviteam Tactics is a hybrid real-time and turn-based strategy game with several layers of organisation and play. The uppermost layer sees you making decisions on an operational scale. You move units across a vast map, you capture points, and you organise supply lines. You've to make sure units have access to command posts and the like. They'll dig in, communicate, repair, and so on on their own, but without a sound commander on their side to tell them where to go, they'll fall apart. Just like real war.

On the ground, GT is one of the best embodiments of war I've ever seen. It is a combat simulator. Your order-giving capacities are limited by the fact that you're using a radio. This means that you can only give so many orders at once. You're someone in a tent with a pair of binoculars and someone transmitting your orders. Give them too many orders, and they'll get confused. They won't hear them. Panic will follow shortly. This means that you've to do the same thing real generals do: you rely on your soldiers' intellect to carry out their tasks. 

[h1]The graphics and simulation[/h1]

Visually speaking, GT doesn't always look great. Their engine is built entirely from scratch, meaning that some of the lighting, shadows, and especially human faces look rather dated. However, if you're going into this as you would into any other combat sim, you're probably not overly concerned. Hell, in comparison to something like the Combat Mission series, I'd say GT looks downright beautiful at times. 

The true kicker of its simulation is the fact that literally nothing is scripted. Everything has physics. If a vehicle stalls going uphill, that isn't because a timer in it told the engine to choke after X minutes, that's the liquid fuel simulation in the engine not reaching its destination. If a bit of ground gives way and a truck rolls over, this is because the pressure in the tire had an effect on the stability of the ground and it gave way. Every bullet, every single shell, every projectile has velocity, and most things have physics collision. I watched a soldier get knocked out by his buddy's helmet as it was being launched by an explosion. It is absolute mayhem, the beautiful, horrifying chaos of total war. 

[h1]So how does it play?[/h1]

It plays as a game of chess. You organise your units, send them to their positions, zoom in, and adjust them. You set them up into lines and columns, find appropriate cover, and then...you press play. 

You watch as your soldier execute their initial orders and hunker down. Sometimes, an entire hour can pass without a single shot. An entire hour of that typical experience of war: waiting, and waiting, and waiting, and waiting. You sit and you wait and you hope there is not a sniper out there with your name on it. 

Victory and defeat can come from anywhere, at any time. They can come from a brilliantly mounted defense or from a single heroic vehicle breaking through against all odds. They can come from the enemy losing their supply at a vital moment or from a carefully executed artillery strike on your part. Be that how it may, it is chaotic, claustrophobic, and at times aggravating - but there is nothing else like it. 

[h1]Should I buy it?[/h1]

That depends. The UI is a nightmare but not nearly as bad as some people say. The recent update to it definitely made it more comprehensible. Read the manual and watch a tutorial or two, but once you got the basics down (except for artillery, setting up telephone wires sucks), you could basically use The Art of War as a strategy manual. 

It's a slow game. Sometimes, it's a boring game, even tedious. Like war, things may not always go to plan. Sometimes, they go the exact opposite way. Operations can last anywhere between 5 hours - around 3 tactical battles for the really small ones - or days upon days as you're scouting every ridge and unit of terrain in a massive all-out front. 

Content-wise, you'll note it's all Eastern Front with some notable exceptions. If you want something more Western, you should grab Tank Combat: Tunisia. The complete version is less than 10 USD on sale and it is the same game as this, only with Americans and British against the fascists. You can defintiely find something you like, from all that's on offer.

[b]TL;DR Hardcore tactical RTS with insanely detailed simulation and excellent AI but a very steep learning curve.[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198058793100', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 49008, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 17, 'playtime_at_review': 28314, 'last_played': 1712443024}
review:
Disclaimer: I received a few complementary DLCs (three latest ones). By that time, I had 500+ hours in the game, not counting Tunisia.

I'm sure most of folks who are reading this review already know about simulation and realism part - great  armor penetration modeling, etc. So I won't concentrate on those aspects, but will instead talk about things that are not as well appreciated, yet should be.

1. Historical context - the way campaigns (operations) are set up, gives players a fairly accurate window into what exactly was going on the particular part of the front, often down to the number and type of heavy weapons in a given unit. It teaches you not to trust theoretical tables of equipment or prescribed order of battle. And you can't help but want to learn more - I discovered that I really enjoy researching WW2 archives trying to get even more details on top of what developers already put into the game. It also obviously increases immersion. Developers keep updating these operations based on the new information that comes out (and they'll use yours - as long as you can provide enough original source documentation!) 
Similarly, the game gives you an excuse to learn say how WW2 artillery worked or about different types of fuses, the entertainment value is endless!

2. Un-RTS nature of this game. There is no: A triggers, therefore B happens. A unit does not have a "vision range" which, once crossed, will result in a spot. There is a function of recognizing the enemy that depends on object size, distance to the object, quality of sites, distraction level of the said unit. Same with movement... There is also a "free will" - your actions never completely define what's going on. While super awesome, this is also a frequent source of grief from players, since that's just not what players are used to. Unfortunately, not many aware of these underlying systems (sometimes we get lucky and developers would explain certain things and it'll just click). But unless developers publish some sort of a white paper (which no one will read anyway:)), this will remain a sore spot for many.

3. Regarding "evil" developers - they are not great at customer management nor do they have a good communication strategy. Which could be frustrating, but I can live with that - it's a game, people, they are not in charge of your bank account. What I've been seeing and can appreciate is that if things are easy to address, the developers will address them. If things require fundamental rework of the underlying engine or the solution is simply not clear, well - they won't. You don't necessarily get to find out which one it is (again, another frequent point of frustration for some). But if a suggestion makes sense, don't be surprised to see it in an update one day even if it's not acknowledged.

4. Speaking of fixes - the game is constantly improved (new cool mechanics are introduced), and it's all free to existing customers. To me, that's really important. But I also enjoy testing out new functionality, while someone else may be upset that they need to re-learn something. DLC's system is nice in a sense that thing most people care about (new tanks - obviously) are also automatically added to the base game. What you pay for in DLC's are new operations, and the maps that go with them. And occasionally developers would release a free operation, just for the heck of it:)

5. While the game is demanding performance-wise, from my naive view it is nicely optimized for what it's doing under the hood. What reminded me of that is a couple of recently played unity-based games where a simple animation would bring my PC to a halt and sure, I only have 1060 with 6GB, but honestly... Yet I digress.

P.S.: Folks are complaining about UI, but I think it has more to do with my point (2) rather than the actual UI itself. Especially those who are long-time wargames players - those things can be cluttered to no end...
P.P.S.: want to provide my take on often raised “AI is brain dead” and “game gives no feedback” points.

6. Ai attacks in hopeless situations- against the tanks, across open fields, etc. This is (in my understanding) done on purpose to simulate uncertainty of waging war at the time. Reading the documents from the era, a lot of the orders were completely blind to the state of the enemy defenses or made extremely optimistic assumptions, which resulted in less than ideal situation on the ground. Translated into the game: on operational map, the overall commander (IRL - division, corps, army, etc) issues an order to  seize territory/dislodge the enemy, etc. On tactical maps, the troops are trying to execute said order, even if that results in what appears to be a very dubious attack. In a similar situation, players (most of us anyway) will completely ignore whatever happened on the operational map and will proceed to (a) scout (b) sit in place if something bad is discovered. 
 
7. AI does not maneuver in tactical battle. While I do wish we had options other than a giant line, a giant column or a giant blob, and that infantry support weapons would be used without needing to babysit them and that a squads would not send a machine gunner to storm the trenches (point being - there are issues, no doubt about it). I also recognize that the “tactics” of an infantry company on the attack had to fit into a zone few hundred meters wide, which does not leave a ton of space for fancy maneuvers. Your choice of tactics comes down to whether to send in the third platoon and what support assets to commit to the mission.

8. Lack of feedback (i.e. we don’t know why a tank does not shoot, why it’s retreating and why is the crew jumping out). Folks argue whether what’s there is sufficient or not (sometimes it is, often it isn’t). But I would challenge you to think from a different perspective: as a battalion/company commander, you would have absolutely no idea what is going on unless it’s right next to you. Forget a company commander - a tank platoon leader is the only one with a radio, how in the world will he know what is happening to his two other tanks. So from that perspective, the amount of information we do get is completely out of place :) With that in mind, if there was an option to get more information, I would probably turn it on when testing out certain situations, but for “ in-character” battle, it’s almost immersion breaking.

One more item I would like to address: realism. We forget at times, that when a game claims to have it (or historical accuracy) it applies to a limited number of aspects. For H&C games it’s likely OOB, for 3-d RTT: appearance of models, etc.

9. There are fundamental limitations to the game’s “realism”.  The transition from node-moving turn-based operation mode to 3-d engagements will always be flawed. Deployment, sequenced moves - the entire discrete word we see in operational phase is very much unrealistic. One can poke holes in it all day :) But let’s be try to be objective while at it: the only game that got away from discrete world in operational space of land-based warfare is Command Ops 2 - no one else bothered. So even the games that don’t need to implement the transition are not jumping on “realism” bandwagon. 
This isn’t meant as discouragement for players seeking best possible experience from expressing their opinions. I am merely suggesting that we try to be “realistic” (pun intended)

author: {'steamid': '76561197995139698', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2777, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 179, 'playtime_at_review': 2116, 'last_played': 1711772923}
review: You kind of have to bumble your way through learning the UI and mechanics but there's something about the spectacle of simulated battle that is unique to this game engine. I realized it as I saw a panzer set aflame by an anti tank shell, its wreck still lurching forward as the crew bailed out, arms flailing as they burned like matchsticks momentarily giving light to a scene of carnage and destruction. Then I laughed because the running around on fire animation is pretty funny.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010772170', 'num_games_owned': 279, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 2860, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1303, 'last_played': 1703484221}
review:
Absolutely brutal. This game actually captures the gravitas, scale, and brutality of WWII like I've always imagined it, and is often showcased in Hollywood films.

I've been searching for the "adult equivalent" of my childhood memories of Sudden Strike and Red Alert for years and years, and holy hell if this isn't exactly that, I don't know what is. I've tried so many of the usual recommendations for modern RTS games, and they always just have a bit too "gamey" of a feel to them, or they require way too much micro managing of each unit that it totally cancels out the actual enjoyment for me. Sure, I know Red Alert and Sudden Strike are insanely "gamey" in hindsight, but my memories of them are somehow very gritty and even tactical, dare I say (probably because hey, for the early 2000's, they kind of were).

Long story short, and to address the UI-shaped elephant in the room: I actually found myself getting to grips with the UI within the first day, and now after just a few days I already feel very comfortable maneuvering troops and reading into all of the info the game throws at you. I'd say the devs have struck an impressive balance here. There is a whole heap of info available to you if you want to drill down and get stuck in, but at the same time the game doesn't require to use everything, nor does it punish you if you choose not to utilize everything. The important stuff is there when you need it, but you can also turn everything off with the click of a button if you want to just enjoy what's on screen. Also kudos to the devs for such great options in the settings menu. You really get to dial in the experience to suit your tastes.

Perhaps my favorite thing about this experience is how cinematic everything is. And no, surprisingly that doesn't mean things feel on rails or out of your control. Quite the opposite. It's because the AI is so adept and well-designed that once you've done your deployment and initial orders for your troops on a more macro and strategic level, your platoons will mostly take care of themselves (and actually make good decisions). Between this and the ability to pause and maneuver a number of cameras around as you see fit (yes, even while paused) you can really pull off some incredible cinematic angles and just sit back and enjoy (or cringe) while your hard work and planning unfolds.

The visuals are actually very impressive, despite some of my early impressions. In fact, for the depth and scale of the game. I think it looks better than most of the smaller scale RTS games out there right now. Very nice job guys.

Above all else, I think the most impressive and addictive aspect of GTMF for me is the realism. It's not hyperbole when people say this is equal parts war sim and RTS game. Between the insane minutiae of tank armor and ballistics modeling, the absolutely fantastic work by Ruki for his sound design (IMO you absolutely MUST download the Ruki SFX mod for this game to truly shine), and just the sheer brutality and scale of the battles you find yourself in, I cannot say I've played a better RTS/war game in my adult life (I'm 32, btw).

Quick note re: DLC: don't be fooled by the usual DLC model employed by most games. For GTMF, all of their DLCs act more like expansions. For example, when you buy one, it adds an additional campaign along with a new map and whatever new units are relevant for that battle. Considering the base game already holds hundreds of hours of gameplay, the fact that these $10-$15 DLCs each add dozens (even hundreds for some) more hours on top of that, I can't applaud them enough for this DLC model. I don't think you'll run out of fresh content anytime soon.

Hands down this is an easy recommendation for anyone interested in WWII, sims, or war games in general. Do not sleep on this.

author: {'steamid': '76561199066069373', 'num_games_owned': 12, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1336, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 651, 'last_played': 1709443365}

author: {'steamid': '76561198022239594', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 26687, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 550, 'playtime_at_review': 8749, 'last_played': 1711553398}
review:
This may not be to everyone's taste but I really like this game, having played the original Combat Mission Beyond Overlord etc, and Combat mission Shock Force I really wanted to give it a go.
It's not a comparison with the above games as it does differ quite a bit you are better off just giving orders let the AI do its thing and then make adjustments, even then you can get into trouble as giving too many orders can use up your command points quickly and confuse your troops!
One of the things I enjoy about this game is the deployment phase of the operation as its critical as in most games to set up your units properly especially AT guns, also the level of detail in the terrain is fantastic!
All that being said its not without faults there is a steep learning curve, there is a manual but it could be a little more detailed but the would people bother reading it? I learn't more from watching tutorials especially from The WarSimmer and also give Tonci87's videos a watch, I learn't a great deal from these guys!
There has been a lot of criticism about the interface too, but to be honest I don't have a problem with it!
In all I would highly recommend this game if you're committed to investing a lot of time to it, don't expect to jump in and start smashing your enemies straight away, but who wants an easy game anyway!
To be fair I did wait for the sales to buy this, but I do with all my games :D

author: {'steamid': '76561197971319628', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 3825, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1210, 'last_played': 1668542077}

author: {'steamid': '76561198041647882', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 24492, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7593, 'last_played': 1708126389}
review: Accepting the fact that this is a simulation more than a game will help you understand how at times you must make do with what you have.  Protect your assets, use proper withdrawals and spring the perfect ambush.  Id your idea of a good war game is to construct the perfect division and capture Moscow and Stalingrad before the first snow of 1941 then you will be in for a letdown.  Right now it is on sale but is really worth any price you pay for it. I would advise anyone to acquire a copy of the game and  plan an attack or a defense and then revel in your victory or withdraw to fight another day 600 yards to the rear of where you are struggling now.  Good Luck and enjoyu.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012855673', 'num_games_owned': 344, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 135, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 133, 'last_played': 1641183237}
review:
Horrible response from developers when issues with the game are brought up. They try to blow bugs and issues off as if everything is working as intended, and there's no reason to fix anything. Even recently making a patronizing post about what artificial intelligence is, or is not. Just go read some of the posts in the game's steam discussion forums. It will absolutely blow your mind how the devs act. Also, no multiplayer... in a game where the AI has big issues.

Also, atrocious UI. For example, the "Start Game" button is a handicap symbol for some reason? (the wheelchair man symbol). And the "Return to main menu" button is a gear icon. Cant tell you how many times I've accidentally quit because I wanted to change an option.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992395260', 'num_games_owned': 410, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 631, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 101, 'last_played': 1659525820}
review:
>Massive 1:1 scale real time battles 
>Even time itself is scaled 1:1 
>Ridiculously deep simulation, wind, air temperature and moisture affects trajectories, temperatures affect viscosity of fuel oil in vehicles, blood loss, organ damage and failure of individual troops affects ability to either fight on or live, every armour plate thickness on every vehicle and impacts of all types of projectile simulated, chance of penetration fully calculated, shells breaking up and fragments pinging around inside the tank causing damage to crew, systems and equipment etc 
>Most realistic command and communications system modeled on realities of battlefield comms, voice, telephone, radio, signal flares etc 
>Massive battlefields, hundreds of square kilometres topographically accurate depictions based on satellite imagery and air recon photography from the time 
>Understanding and use of real world tactics not only helpful, they are essential in order to do well 
>Battlefield deformation and persistence, craters from artillery, destroyed buildings, wrecked equipment, dead troops, destroyed buildings etc litter the field for the rest of the operation 
>Incredibly kino, manages to conjure atmosphere like no other game out there, from the lighting to the landscape, it's a wonderfully evocative representation of man killing man in the natural world. 
>Weather and day/night cycles fully simulated, the sun rises or falls, mist hangs in the air but may slowly clear if that's what was reported by commanders at the time, heavy rain and snow severely affects not just your units ability to see but also to hear the enemy. All in all peak milsim autism

author: {'steamid': '76561197969756605', 'num_games_owned': 223, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 8323, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6139, 'last_played': 1701704125}
review:
I came across this game a few months ago but steered clear of it when I saw the UI and the massive investment in time to understand the game. I've always been a fan of WW2 strategy games such as Company of Heroes, Close Combat Series, and Combat Mission but these never really scratched the itch I had for large scale, operational level campaigns with tactical battles. 

I was bored one morning and decided to buy this and give it a whirl. First and foremost, this game presents a an opportuntiy for you to be a German or Russian commander on the ostfront leading company size battlegroups across different stages of the Russian compaign from 1941 to 1943 (depending on the DLC you buy). When you choose a specific campaign within the game you immediately get taken to the Operational Mode of the game which lets you put on your commander hat and move your platoons across a very accurate (and simulated on real topology data from the time) map based on turns. In this mode you can move units, attack sectors, reinforce units, place units in defence (where they build trenches) and many other things. This mode is quite possibily my favourite part of the game as it gives you a unique opportunity to plan your strategy, your flanking manvouevers, your order of battle before executing the turn and letting the AI take their turn. It during this time that the AI calculates your move + the opponents move to determine which sectors will be be involved in the next battle, or which sectors you can capture without incident. Depending on the scale of the campaign you chose (i.e. number of units in that campaign or density of the map) you can quite easily get to a point where there are numerous battles after just one turn.

Its at this point that I will say that very little about this game is intuitive. In fact, its a nightmare, even with tutorials, to figure out what everything means on the map and how to get the units to do what you want. I had to watch dozens of videos on youtube to figure it out but when you do it really opens up and you can see why this game has so many loyal fans which hundreds of hours invested.

Once you get into battle you are taken to the tactical map where the real fun begins. This is where the game starts to feel more like Combat Mission where you get to control platfoon and squad level units, position them, create fire mission zones, or give initial orders before hitting the go button to start the battle in real time. A lot of people say that this game shines best as a simulator, where you give your orders, turn off the annoying UI and just watch the battle unfold. Some even say that the game is best played as "hands off" as possible. 

My perspective is that, yes the battles are incredible to watch play out. The attention to detail is stunning. Each soldier, each unit, each weapon has datapoints associated with them as well as animations that I've never seen in a game trying to do this at this scale. Tanks get hit, crew members bail out on fire, tank rolls down hill before hitting a tree - all completely unscripted. I've seen assault pioneers jump out of halftracks, throw smokes grenades before charging trench systems and artillery blow of tank tranks. Its so damn fun to watch each battle play out or zoom into individual actions of units where each has a story to tell. Having said all that, sometimes there is so much going on at one time that you need to hit the pause button, zoom out, turn back on the UI and start giving orders again. 

I found that I enjoyed this game as a simulator, but i also enjoyed being able to change my orders, create flanks with tanks or re-adjust artillery patterns in real time. The game does punish you for giving out "too many orders" as a way to simulate command chatter during battle so once units are commiited its hard to pull them back which makes its even more fun as every step you take has to be careful and well planned out.

Yes the UI sucks but I can see that it has been improved over the last year through patches. Nevertheless, it took me a long time (and i'm still learning) to figure out how to coordinate indirect artillery, dismount or segment units (into fireteams) but once you do it just adds more flourish and options to playing the game.

The game gives you 100's of hours of gameplay and I own pretty much all of the DLC (each DLC can be anywhere from 10-30 hours). Every DLC i have played is brilliant so far, each brining new units such as Panthers, Tigers and those big bad ass russian tanks that have the 120mm turrets (ouch)

Anyway, this game is probably the best WW2 strategy game I have played. It is not for the light hearted but if you give it time you will learn to love this and be amazed how a small dev team could turn out such a deep and comprehensive battle simulator.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006665028', 'num_games_owned': 1057, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 13304, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 511, 'playtime_at_review': 6860, 'last_played': 1712420172}

author: {'steamid': '76561198154344973', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1253, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 32, 'last_played': 1704126457}
review:
I criticized the game's AI in the forum, and Andrey the developer responded in his typical ruthless manner, attacking my comments, saying it was too vague and not helpful. I responded by providing details and suggestions, making sure I was thorough. In a week Andrey published a patch fixing the AI problem I was talking about.

All I wanted to say is: you cannot be thin-skinned and solve problems. The best way to understand a problem is to attack it from all angles. You are of no help if you get mad, just get your message through. "Correctness" is the plague of our times. All those who are in charge know is being nice but they achieved nothing.

This is the best wargame I've ever played. I understand it's not for everyone. It can be difficult the way a flight sim is difficult: it's not bad design, it's meant to be that way. I don't play flight sims, I play arcade shooters. For those who don't like this game, you should play one of those WWII-themed RTS instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024398153', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 9038, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9002, 'last_played': 1689226372}
review:
The most important thing to understand is that this is a SIMULATION, not a game. 
Yes, there is a learning curve, yes it will be very challenging at first, but once you learn the mechanics, this is (IMO) the best wargame simulation available for commercial purchase. 

If you have patience, enjoy strategic thinking and are a fan of historical scenarios, this product is a must own.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045164841', 'num_games_owned': 842, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 289, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 289, 'last_played': 1624391523}
review:
I’m starting this list with a banger. Mius Front is the ultimate World War II tactical experience with a 1:1 scale. No game does it better, not even Combat Mission. This enough is sure to stir up emotions- discussions about everyone’s taste are due to arise. Yes, it focuses only on the Eastern Front and zooms into very specific operations, but what it does, does so in a phenomenal, perfectly executed way. Indeed, what’s not up for debate is the quality and sheer amount of small detail every new DLC brings to the table- meticulously recreated orders of battles, dozens of square miles of new locations to fight on, 3D models that can make even the pickiest of wargamers blush. Its battles are disturbingly realistic, working as a perfect Swiss clock with all the small pieces coming together to a perfect cadence. It’s the most authentic depiction of World War 2 to ever grace monitor screens. The two major setbacks are a lack of comprehensive tutorials and an indecipherable UI that makes the Volnichs manuscript easy to decrypt by comparison. Those can make your life miserable for a while but persevere and the tactical game goodness is just beyond the learning curve. When it comes to the Eastern Front, Graviteam Tactics: Mius Front is to the tactical plane of warfare what War in the East 2 is to the operational level. In fact, I have a theory that if you could crack open War in the East 2, dozens of Graviteam Tactics battles would be raging within.

You can read more about WW2 games here [url=https://strategyandwargaming.com/] Strategy and Wargaming [/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561198000041123', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 7382, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 454, 'last_played': 1710217529}
review:
A true hidden gem. All of the Graviteam Tactics games are, Tank Warfare included. The UI is very obtuse, though not impossible to understand by any means; it just takes time. If you can get through that and understand how combat flows, you're in for one of the most authentic and well-realized war simulations ever made.

Every single engagement feels dynamic and important, from the smallest firefight between two infantry platoons to a pitched and devastating brawl between entire tank companies with air, artillery and mechanized support. For example, I was playing a defense mission as the Soviets in the On The Luga Line DLC. The Germans managed to sneak an AT company in the forest between two of my own companies, forcing me to set up two separate defensive lines. In order to take the heat off of my frontline, I had a recon platoon scour that forest. They managed to ambush the Pak guns before they could set up and wreck my own AT, which was important because a German tank company was also in the fray.

Said tanks seemed to realize that they were about to go up against a hardened front, so they tried to take a back road to flank my second defensive line, which had no AT. If those tanks reached that line, they would've wiped my entire backline out, so I sent two infantry squads further into the forest to ambush them on the road they were taking. They only had rifles, grenades and molotovs, but it was my faint hope that they would at least disrupt the tank column's cohesion just enough to buy myself more time. Imagine my surprise that when those two squads ambushed the column, the plan actually worked; they managed to take out two tanks and force the others to divert off the road and into the forest to avoid them, which slowed them down significantly. This attack actually caused the enemy's will to break and they offered me a cease fire. That one small engagement completely separate from the heavy fighting at the two fronts changed the course of the battle. I've never had an experience quite like that in any other strategy game. It felt so damn rewarding.

There is no other game on the market that simulates battalion-level warfare nearly as well as Graviteam Tactics.

author: {'steamid': '76561198319844992', 'num_games_owned': 307, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 39286, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1900, 'playtime_at_review': 1290, 'last_played': 1712456596}

author: {'steamid': '76561197981918195', 'num_games_owned': 357, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 377, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 274, 'last_played': 1641686877}
review: Yes, just yes

author: {'steamid': '76561197970498450', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 460, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 447, 'last_played': 1639746120}
review:
Unfortunately this is a flawed masterpiece.
After putting 50 hours in Operation Star I got back to Mius Front after some time and I had to re-learn everything. The UI is beyond obtuse and it completely disrespects every rule out there. To make the matter worse the documentation is awful and this whole situation forces you to invest dozens of hours of try and error to understand how the game works and reasons.
This is not how a videogame is meant to be designed and produced. Design-wise the UI is the core of the interaction and if you fail at it you are undermining the whole gameplay and fun (which is the point of playing the game). Production-wise, if you fail to create an approachable and enjoyable learning process you are dooming the user to hours of pain which, again, undermine the whole gameplay and fun (again ,the point of a game).
If you fail at these there is no brilliant game that can salvage the disaster. Any single masterpiece in the history of videogames would have been a disaster if the UI and the learning process wouldn't have been taken care properly.

The fact that this game is somewhat successfull clearly shows how strategy players are willing to endure everything in order to find a good strategic experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198182935227', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 5519, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4635, 'last_played': 1692611171}

author: {'steamid': '76561198020720135', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 292, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 201, 'last_played': 1680971215}
