review: Probably the premier WW2 Easter Front battlefield simulator. Effort is required to learn the interface and mechanics but the community is always helpful and there are a great series of videos showing the  required aspects of gameplay. Once it clicks (as it is starting to do for me) it is a real joy to play. Worth noting the range of battles the devs have decided to model, much more than the usual WW2 Eastern Front fare. Well worth a look.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097467630', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 14701, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3253, 'last_played': 1696730129}
review: Yes I absolutely recommend this game. People say the learning curve is steep I respectfully disagree. The controls are hefty but they work in the way you expect an RTS to work, some of the smaller aspects about the game take a little digging but most of it is self explanatory. What I believe people struggle with is clicking on your troops and immediately expecting results. The game is slow and methodical and you learn through bitter defeat. It's easy to quit when you watch your soldiers die from things that seem like the games fault but is actually yours. After watching your Pak-38 shells bounce helplessly off of T-34's rolling across your lines, you learn slowly to hide them telling them to hold fire until they are within 300 meters and letting loose on their vulnerable sides. You learn how to coordinate your artillery fire and even schedule it like you would in real life. You learn how to utilize terrain to its maximum advantage and using support to push yourself to victory.  At 54 hours of gameplay, I am just now finally beginning to see the fruit of my hard work. Put the time in and be patient, you will love the results.

author: {'steamid': '76561198256800566', 'num_games_owned': 216, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 25668, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15577, 'last_played': 1683903081}
review:
Играю уже в течении нескольких лет, пару сотню часов Стим показывает. Игра интересная. Требует собранности, от решений и кликов в оперативном моде кампании зачастую зависит, какие впечатления получите от тактической, трёхмерной фазы. Для невдумчивой игры есть генератор случайных миссий, с возможностью предустановки войск и условий. За динамикой и экшеном можно обратиться туда. Игра микроконтроль, прокликивания юнитов по 100 раз в минуту и резкую смену планов не поощряет, потому танковые сражения на близкой дистанции особенно запоминаются. Неожиданности случаются, и необходимость принимать решения с пониманием того, что потери невосполнимы - притягивают людей в эту игру. В базовые понятия и команды игра вводит через вкладку обучающих сценариев и текстовое руководство (в pdf).
Нравится, играю в новые сценарии по мере их выхода. Также существует Tank Warfare, как расширение сеттинга игры на Африку в 1942-43 годах.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988240414', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 11971, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4606, 'last_played': 1700780415}
review:
BLUF: Easily the best battlegroup-level simulator on the market, despite some obtuse design decisions and a shockingly anti-social Dev-team.

Graviteam Tactics: Mius Front is an excellent game. It's obsessively detailed, beautiful to look at, and easily the most accurate and true-to-life simulator you can get your hands on. Everything from ranges to line of sight are modelled to the inch, but not just that: Watch an individual road-wheel bounce up and down as a tank negotiates a patch of rough ground; watch a well-spaced convoy advance along a road (no unsightly Steel Divison-esque traffic jams here); watch the crew of an abandoned heavy weapon creep back to it after the fighting has died down and try to effect repairs. 
Fire-fights are satisfyingly real in the way that they ebb and flow, as soldiers lose sight of the enemy, re-load, become suppressed or try to advance. Tanks exchange fire over staggering distances, artillery feels like the god-like wrath which it truly was... as long as there's someone in a position to talk the fire onto the target. The level of detail and effort that has been sunk into this game is truly staggering. Clearly, the game stands on its own merits as a WW2 simulator.

And that's just as well, because all of that quality is well-hidden behind a bafflingly complex control schematic. While the surface layers are intuitive enough, useful tools like the ability to walk artillery fire, or separate off a transport from its passengers, are hidden within a clumsily worded, badly translated, sparsely illustrated manual tucked away on the game's store page. Crucial mechanics, like the game's overly literal interpretation of how Artillery Fire Missions were called in, are poorly explained and remain topics of confusing claim and counter-claim on the forum pages. And the game's Developers are abrupt to the point of rudeness, making no secret of their disdain for player feed-back and engagement. 

Ultimately, if you enjoy strategy- real strategy- and simulators; if you've military experience or an interest in WW2 History; and if you're willing to spend several hours watching video tutorials from helpful youtubers; then you'll get a lot out of this game. But be aware that it isn't Steel Division, and it isn't Men of War, and it certainly isn't Company of Heroes. It's a gem, if a slightly rough one, which could have achieved a much wider acclaim beyond the narrow field of strategy nuts, if it weren't for some wilfully obtuse decisions on the part of the Devs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035757748', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 176, 'playtime_forever': 434, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 122, 'last_played': 1640527017}

author: {'steamid': '76561197967538447', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 21404, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1436, 'last_played': 1688392463}
review: After some initial hiccups with performance expectations and trying a couple of the dlcs right away I've come to appreciate this is by far the best battalion sized wargame ever made. Stick with it. It runs like shit occasionally. You will have to play with some limited sized engagements sometimes if you want over 30 fps. I usually prefer high and stable fps but as long as this game is running smooth enough (freesync helps a lot with this game) to play without wincing over some occasional studdering when all hell is breaking loose in a battle, than im ok with it. The gameplay more than makes up for it. If youre a wargaming nerd and enjoy games like close combat, steel division 2, hoi, panzer corps etc, give this one more than look and put the little bit of time to understand the mechanics of the ui. I Think youll be rewarded with a great experience like I have.

review:
Die beste und realistischste 2.Weltkriegssimulation die ich bisher gespielt habe.Das sagt ein alter Sack der schon "Close Combat A bridge too far "in den 90zigern gezockt hat.Man muss sich ein wenig reinfuchsen.Man hat dann aber alle Möglichkeiten(im voraus geplante Artillerieschläge,Reserven selbst bestimmen,umkoordinieren der Kampfgruppen,Bewegung auf der Karte und zu guter Letzt die einzelnen Gefechte ,die an Intensität nicht zu überbieten sind.)Klare Kaufempfehlung!

author: {'steamid': '76561198006199598', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 4677, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2211, 'last_played': 1569000822}
review:
Disappointed by steel division's micro management feast and a game mode that on one hand has very artificial structure and yet try to be realistic in unit level. 

This game is a rough diamond. Once I got pass the UI confusion, it is a great experience playing the battle, both realistic and fun to play. AI is great for both sides. Command chain is modelled, voice is useless under barrage, phone line might be cut and need to be laid agin....Visual is super detailed and very impressive given the scale of the game. 

Oh and did I mention that ballistics is modelled for every bullet? and great physics. Yesterday I saw a T34 charging towards my trench got one shot kill from Pak40 on the side and continued rolling forward thanks to its momentum. And in another place I saw a soviet solider kicking my suppressed gun man to death... 

still struggling to fully understand how the operation mode works, but worth every penny. Really really hope the dev make some effort on the manual to explain all the intricacies.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003461278', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 5458, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1793, 'last_played': 1710282861}
review:
First of all, if you are considering the purchase of this game, don't think about it any longer. Buy  it! You won't regret it. Ignore the negative reviews as I made the mistake of thinking that getting into this game would be too complicated and it would take too much time because of them. Granted, the UI is not very good (it's the weakest part of the game actually) and yes, the tutorials are lacking. BUT, thanks to the community, there are excellent tutorials on youtube to learn the basics. Once you know what each button does and how the game mechanics work, the game becomes very straightforward. 

I was looking for a good WW2 tactical game since I discovered the Close Combat series in my teens and the only thing that came close to that experience was the Theatre of War franchise which was quite good but had many flaws. I tried Combat Mission but I just could not get into it. I had given up hope until I found Graviteam Tactics. There is much less micromanaging in this game than in those mentioned but on the other hand you need to plan your battles more carefully during the deployment phase or you'll get seriously wrecked by the AI.

As I mentioned earlier, I was initially put off by reviews complaining about the UI and the steep learning curve but I'm glad I finally decided to give it a go. Oh boy indeed how glad I am! Battles are extremely rewarding if you take your time to plan them carefully during the deployment phase. 
Once the battle starts, it is a dream come true for any WW2 buff. Tracers iluminate the sky, vehicles get crippled and show damage depending on where they were hit, troops surrender, soldiers panic, battlefield destruction is persistent, crew jump (in flames) out of burning vehicles, realistic penetration trajectories for projectiles... the attention to detail is astonishing and the graphics are great!   

No base building, no resource gathering, no frantic clicking around the map, no magical summoning of units...  just you, your troops and your wits.

I've tried many WW2 games in my years but none are as immersive and fun as this one (except close combat maybe ;p)

PS.I also purchased Tunisia Tank Warfare which is the same game set in the North African theatre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198811609354', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 15, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15, 'last_played': 1564055024}
review: 还是需要中文，英语只会一些基本的

author: {'steamid': '76561197960948341', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 46554, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 178, 'playtime_at_review': 7967, 'last_played': 1711841656}
review:
Compared to the previous graviteam tacitcs : operation star it is worth it to purchase this one. 

Graphics are slightly updated, the most noticeable was the artillery effects. 

The new static map trenches are fun to play in and are significantly better than self-made dug in ones.

Planes are OP death machines now. Before they were lackluster, maybe scoring one tank or field gun kill if you lucky. Now they cripple an entire tank platoon. It will kill 3 or 4 vehicles and damage another 2. Good thing they only come once a day a now instead of every battle. 

The AI is slightly updated. It still loves to waste artillery shells on flag points with blind pre-planned fire at the start of the round. On the attack It does better with combining infantry and tanks but needs work still. The attacks are not full force but one at a time. With only one or two units supporting each other at a time. The "line" problem when the computer would have the infantry attack in marching line has been worked on. It still happens but only occasionally. Counter battery have been greatly improved. After firing artillery guns or AT field guns the AI will reposition them to avoid artillery fire. No longer can I scout and then call in 10 min off map artillery strike and expect it to kill anything on the last known position. 

This game could be so much better with multiplayer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076564084', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 803, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 803, 'last_played': 1559178324}
review: Как абсолютно точно написал кто-то, это не симулятор боя с врагом, а симулятор боя со своими войсками. Минометная батарея обстреливает врага, после чего перемещаешь ее вместе с командиром на другую точку, командир врага видит, связь действует, а минометы не стреляют. Хоть застрелись! Или наступает твое подразделение на траншеи врага, откуда ведется огонь. Бойцы вместо того, чтобы в три прыжка достичь траншей, спрыгнуть в них и начинать косить врага, ложатся на брюхо в десятке метров от траншей и крутятся на одно месте во все стороны как припадочные, пока их всех до одного не выкашивают. Короче. ИИ тупой как пробка. Живет своей жизнью

author: {'steamid': '76561198120389495', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 17143, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 465, 'last_played': 1708742786}
review: lets just say after playing this game I have massive amounts of respects to all the battalion/division commanders in every army during ww2, shits fucking brutal given like 6 t-34s and some 45mm anti tank guns and being asked to arrange a defense or an offense in such a fashion to repel like 3 panther platoons and a tiger platoon or having only 3 operational panthers and arranging them in such a way that artillery doesnt have a chance to disable/knock them out as well as dealing with a massive onslaught of t-34's and infantry to the last man. But this is why the game is so fun, you get to experience the frustration and brutality of warfare in the sense of absolute attrition but never have to be in these scenarios yourself (hopefully).

author: {'steamid': '76561198271172614', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 37801, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7985, 'last_played': 1711148866}
review:
Довольно давно наблюдаю за данным проектом и вот моё следующее мнение:
Плюсы:
+ ИИ шикарен и может задать жару, но только в том случае, если фаза боя в настройках выставлена 2 часа и более. ИИ - противник в 80% случаев не станет атаковать Вас в лоб, первые минут 30 боя может обстреливать Ваши позиции из артиллерии и разведчиками прощупывать слабые места в обороне, если у Вас мало войск, то будет пробовать взять Вас в кольцо и перестрелять как уток или же выматывать Ваши войска постоянными волнами нападений и отступлений.
+ Настоящий военный симулятор! Никаких полосок жизни, если попал снаряд в отряд из 10 человек, значит у Вас уже нет этих 10-и человек.
+ Погодные эффекты и сама местность очень сильно влияют на бой и выглядят шикарно.
+ Игру не забрасывают, довольно часто выходят годные DLC.
Теперь перейдём непосредственно к минусам:
- Управление войсками оставляет желать лучшего, надеюсь, с будущими обновлениями управление войсками станет лучше.
- В игре есть мины, мины делают хороший БА-БА-АХ, можно эти мины снимать пехотой, но самим, в случае обороны, - ставить нельзя.

Вряд ли разработчики увидят мой комментарий, но я всё же оставлю пожелание того, чего бы хотел увидеть в игре.
Было бы шикарно сыграть битву на территории не каких-нибудь безымянных деревенек, а в больших городах, где можно действительно устраивать неплохие засады на технику в узких улочках или пехотой биться за площади, проспекты или другие стратегические зоны, а уж какой разгул для артиллерии и авиации можно устроить!

author: {'steamid': '76561198035741405', 'num_games_owned': 311, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 6667, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 639, 'last_played': 1706670148}
review:
Its insane to me that ive only just discovered this game, I have been looking for this type of ww2 simulation for years and now i've finally found it! There are issues with the game like lack of tutorials for campaign, and a clunky UI, also i really wish there were auto resolves for campaign since id rather not spend an hour waiting for the battle to be over. plus no multiplayer

The positive on the other hand outweighs the rest, the realism of battle, the slow paced action that really makes you feel like you're there. The graphics are very well done, they're not ground breaking by any means but still good enough to warrant praise. I really like that you don't need to micro everything and just worry about the battle at hand, which is a good break from every RTS that is out there. This is definetly a hardcore sim and i'm not sure how more realistic a game can get for battlefields. and the AI is actually quite smart, it'll try to outflank you, bombard your positions.

Anyways buy this game! I just have no idea why this game wasn't marketed a little bit more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056653904', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 11592, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2515, 'last_played': 1693932334}
review: The game at its core is a great WW2 simulator of what combat on the eastern front must have been like. However the UI is incredibly clunky. Units under your command dont respond particulary well to orders. Russia seems to have a bias in terms of tanks and AT guns. You will often find your well placed AT emplacements being one-shotted by russian T-34's and your panther/tiger tanks losing out in a duel against russian armour. If the game were more combat balanced i would say buy but at the moment only get it if on sale and if you are a big fan of the eastern front during ww2.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018029296', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 4017, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 240, 'last_played': 1690588758}
review:
Такие игры как Graviteam Tactics обычно окружены немногочисленной, но очень занудной и мерзкой толпой задротов, которые мнят себя как минимум Роммелем, Николаем Федоровичем Ватутиным и Омаром Брэдли  в одном лице. Даже здесь, в обзорах стима, они строчат свои простыни с особо важным "мнением" по всем возможным и невозможным вопросам военной тактики и отпугивают "казуальных" игроков - мол Гравитим Тактикс игра сложная, "не для всех", сначала закончи военное училище а потом играй, а то, не дай Бог, проиграешь!

Не стоит верить этим клоунам. Graviteam Tactics игра очень интересная, хотя и не самая простая для освоения. Для любого человека который имеет базовое представление о том, как велись боевые действия Второй Мировой войны понять ее основные принципы будет несложно, а играть будет довольно весело.  Главное помнить, что в этой игре имеет большое значение связь и командование, поэтому не надо разбрасывать свои войска по всей карте и постоянно отдавать им новые приказы противоречащие друг другу, а держать отряды под контролем офицеров, иначе на поле боя начнется полный цирк и хаос. И не надо бояться ошибаться и проигрывать - война это не  наука и не искусство, а смесь ошибок, провалов, идиотизма командиров и неразберихи, в которой иногда проглядывают зачатки чего-то разумного.  

Недостатков у Гравитим Тактикс полно - не особо удобный интерфейс, туповатый ИИ, пехотный бой по сравнению с более "простыми" РТС тип  COH и Mowas 2 выглядит смешно и  убого. Постепенно к этому привыкаешь и начинаешь относиться с иронией.  Но плюсы перевешивают - это возможность двигать войска по глобальной карте , выдумывать всякие засады и угарные маневры,  прикольные танковые бои и исторические штаты подразделений. 

Для тех кто уже играл в первую часть изменения будут заметны сразу. Помимо улучшенного графона, искусственный идиот все таки уже на такой уж и идиот. Здорово прет в атаке, не дает передышки, пехота уже не так отстойно взаимодействует с танками как в первой части, также комп  побольше бомбит артиллерией и даже иногда придумывает какие-то маневры кроме лобового спринта прямо на заряженные пулеметы. Конечно, иногда этот гений тактики выдает и откровенные приколы, вроде наступления под перекрестным огнем по чистому полю, ну что тут сказать, диды и не такое еще придумывали в 1941-45.   Ну и бои на Миус-Фронте выглядят покруче и масштабнее возни в сугробах под Харьковом. 


В целом игру рекомендую всем кто плотно интересуется историей Второй мировой войны - получите хороший расслабон и заряд позитива. Главное не победа, а участие!

author: {'steamid': '76561198026022307', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 3938, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 76, 'playtime_at_review': 3773, 'last_played': 1712230232}
review:
Игру купил с релиза и до сих пор в эту игру просто невыносимо играть.
1. Тупейший ии бронетехники. По курсу движения куст? Срочно объехать! И пофиг, что по танку долбит 3 ПТО. Количество бессмысленных подставлений борта просто зашкаливает, такое ощущение, что это не танк, а бтр на колесах, который боится застрять в любой ямке. Так же совершенно не понятно что со скоростью техники. Почему все еле ползет не по дорогам? Грузовики, БТР, танки все ползет со скоростью пехоты иногда, при приказе быстрого передвижения. Я смотрел много разных документальных фильмов с хроникой, так вот там техника так не ползает. Да, танки тут по сути не умеют двигаться и стрелять с "короткой". Вместо этого будет смесь тупизма в подставлении борта врагу + стрельба по командиру с пистолетом, в то время как по курсу танка стоит арта + вражеские танки.
2. Совершенно не понятная стрельба арты/танков. Стандартная ситуация когда танк выстрелил по вражескому танку, перезарядился иииииии, и все, светится линия стрельбы, но стрелять танк больше не хочет, при том, что цель видит. Та же фигня и с артой запросто может быть.
3. Стрельба по площади. Это просто супер не очевидная хрень. Командир видит место, которое нужно обстрелять, арта может попасть туда с закрытой позиции, но стрелять она не будет, просто потому что. Или из 4 пушек стреляет одна без каких-либо видимых причин.
4. Пехота так же как будто без глаз. Только что видел как бежит солдат с ППШ на пушку, которая только что стрельнула и перезаряжается, так он просто ломится на нее даже не пытаясь обстрелять. Перестрелки пехоты вообще зрелище не для слабонервных, хочется иногда лицо фейспалмом разбить.
5. ОЧЕНЬ часто командиры, да и просто техника/пехота смотрит НЕ в направлении врага. Командир арт. батареи смотрит на саму батарею - так это вообще в порядке вещей. Даже если его специально повернуть в сторону врага, через минут эдак 5 этот имбецил так же будет таращиться куда-то, где совсем нет врага.
Иногда приходится чуть ли не каждому танку в отдельности выставлять сектора обзора и даже после этого, запросто может ехать на врага и повернуть пушку в совершенно другую сторону.

В целом игра создает ощущение боя с собственными войсками, а не с войсками врага. Сколько раз у меня горел стул из-за непроходимой тупости ИИ войск. И да, я смотрел и читал разные мануалы, знаю как работают механики игры, но работает это все криво и косо и за 3 года почти ничего не поменялось (ну хоть арта начала двигаться куда ей приказывают, а не вставать на месте через каждые 5 метров)
И вот к этому всему добавляется еще и чудовищный низкий фпс от дыма (падения до 10 фпс), например (пресет "высокие качество")
Ryzen 5 2600x, Gigabyte X470 Aorus Ultra Gaming, 16Gb DDR4 3000MHz Patriot Viper Steel, Palit GeForce RTX 2070 dual.
Идея игры просто 10 из 10, а реализация на троечку :-(

author: {'steamid': '76561198127377037', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 18254, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5190, 'last_played': 1710283963}
review: If you were like me, and had been searching steam and the internet for hours looking for a realistic, hardcore but fun to play strategy game then you've just found it. I will be honest, if you have no experience with games similar to this you will struggle at first to get to grips with this game, however, once you get familiar with how it works you will really see why its so good. Whats so good about this game is that there is nothing else like it, and yet it does such a good job of presenting war in a realistic way. Communications, morale,ammunition, command influence and much more all impact how you command and manage your troops in this game.

if you've ever been annoyed by the lack of scale in military rts/strategy games then look no further, because you'll find it here on the battle maps, recreated more meticulously and realistically than I've seen in other games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198289901075', 'num_games_owned': 110, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 34448, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1, 'playtime_at_review': 7582, 'last_played': 1712091950}
review:
Graviteam Tactics: Mius-Front is the successor of Graviteam Tactics: Operation Star. First of all, don't expect gameplay like in Company of Heroes or Men of War, if you already played these titles. Everything is much slower and you need to take much more time to think about a good strategy (troop placement, good flanking routes, ambush positions, artillery/mortar/AT/HMG spots, take care about the weather conditions or the day and night circle), if you want to be a successful player. At the beginning you won't be able to understand the UI completely, there it's a little bit complicated. I can give you the advice to look for good guides on Youtube or read some stuff on the Graviteam forum. Otherwise you won't get a grip of it, because everything works quite different. 

The maps you play on are recreated areas, where the soldiers fought during WW2, so no fictional stuff, even the amount of troops who fought during the certain battles were recreated. Mostly wide and open areas up to 3×3km², filled with smaller and medium-sized villages, hillside, rivers, woodland, a high variety in fauna and different surface conditions. One negative point is the AI, which can be faulty from time to time but also not too often and is in general more advanced compared to Operation Star. 

If you finished the campaigns, you are able to create your own battles with all different types of units, which gives the game a high replayability. The developers are also helpful, if you have any questions on Steam and mostly listen to the community. The DLC's are great and add some modern campaigns, for example the Angola conflict or the Iran-Iraq war. I can definitely also recommend other Graviteam titles, like Operation Star and Tank Warfare: Tunisia 1943.

Differences compared to Operation Star:

-More tactical depth
-Better AI
-Overworked UI
-A lot of new units available
-Fortifications added to the battlefield (minefields, barb wired fences, tank traps, different types of bunkers, big trench systems)
-Better graphics

In conclusion, an unique niche game, which have a very steep learning curve for beginners. It's very unforgiving and you have to virtually pay for every mistake you make in your decisions. If you don't be afraid of that, you should simply buy it. 

Have fun!

author: {'steamid': '76561198122106087', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 9815, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 164, 'playtime_at_review': 2759, 'last_played': 1711301563}
review:
Mius Front, ah what a game.  I love it to pieces, but I cant recommend it to anyone else.  This game is easily the most headache inducing thing I have ever experienced (and I have a little brother), and im going to break down why into four simple points:

UI:  Everyone complains about the UI, but why?  Because aside from looking bad, it just doesnt function the way a UI should.  There will be moments in battle where you need immediate fire support from your mortar platoon, but no matter what you do, they will not fire.  There has to be a reason for this, but it is nearly impossible to figure it out because the UI doesnt provide any useful information to the player.  Yes, you have statistics on the left side about each unit, but that just tells you WHAT the unit is doing, and never WHY they are doing it.  A simple notification of "Hey, they wont shoot here be *insert reason*" would be fantastic.  This lack of information is endemic of almost all UI functions in the game and is easily the most frustrating part.

Responsiveness:  Actions in the game just dont feel good.  Most of the time when you give a direct order to a unit you have no idea what it is going to do next.  It could:

A. do nothing 
B. Run around in circles for about five minutes until it actually decides to go where you asked it
C. Go on a completely random path (usually a detrimental one) to your destination for no visible reason
or D. Actually follow orders and do what you asked it to

This may be somewhat realistic (for the most part I believe that commanders on the level of this game had more control than is given to the player), but it is incredibly unfun.  You dont want to roll the dice each time you give a crucial order, you want to see your units actually at least try to do what you asked.  Sometimes this situation is caused by the afformentioned UI issues, because you cant see information on why a unit wont move.  But I feel most of the time units wont do what you ask because of simple programming errors on the developers part (It is hard to effectively path a map as large as they have here).  Overall, when you click a button, you want something to happen (or at least be told why it wont happen) , and in Mius front most of the time that just doesnt happen.

AI:  Its bad, im just going to say that right now.  You can have two guys just meters apart, staring right at each other, and they will just sit there, not firing for literally minutes.  Its not cinematic or cool to watch, its just frustrating and laughable.  It gets even worse with tanks and anti tank guns.  You have a perfectly placed anti tank gun, which has a great shot on an enemy tank like 30 meters away, and it will just sit there idly, as if nothing is going on.  That tank will go on to destroy the anti tank gun without it firing a shot.  There may be a reason for this, but the UI doesnt work well enough to tell me.  Im pretty sure it is the AI, because sometimes the Anti tank will suddenly "see" the tank that was right in front of it the whole time and fire.  The whole immersion of the battlefield is ruined by these moments because you realize that these are just rendered robots fighting each other (and not very well)

Airforces:  Holy. Fucking. Shit.  They will wreck your day and there is not a fucking thing you can do about it.  There is nothing more frustrating than setting up a defense for an hour, only to see enemy planes coming over the horizon.  You have no counter (other than small arms fire, which doesnt do shit) as you watch the enemy tear apart well placed trenches and vehicles.  NO ONE, likes to feel like everything they do doesnt matter, and the airforces give people that feeling in spades.  Just a quick balance patch, give them less bombs, maybe make them leave faster due to fuel shortage. I dont know, just do SOMETHING, its not that hard.

In conclusion, MIUS FRONT has its moments but overall is a terrifically frustrating experience.  If you want to have a heart attack at the age of thirty over a video game, you have your answer in MIUS FRONT (or any of the other graviteam tactics game, because they all have the same problem as this one).

author: {'steamid': '76561198213619315', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 16755, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12163, 'last_played': 1709761532}
review:
If you ever wanted a game where you need TWO <2> Desk tops  ?   Why ? You may ask ?   ~  don't look any further .  The game we all wanted when we  were learning Stratego and Risk .  A game where your supply lines matter / your will matters , the men matter . Your superb knowledge as a military historian matter's /  Your drive to achieve the impossible , matter ! This concept~ simulator~ will make you beg for action !  You will not sleep until you can achieve total victory ! 

You will be the General !  Command  Inf/ Mech/Arty/ Armor  units historically , in the same  theme of the Eastern Front .  The only thing missing is the regalia of an age they want to forget .  Hoist your flags , destroy or defend  !  The only thing missing is naval action and guirilla tactics .  Land battles of spectacular design take you into the battle like never before . The sound of the battle will rock the neighbors  !  Head phones not included !


Your 1st desk top to play and cruise the web ~ &   2nd to dedicate to your campaign .  This simulator will pull you out of your trench and throw you in the air like a meatpuppet .  The atmosphere and moment will draw you in like a General of equal mishaps .  Your Honor and pride will make you attack ! Your humility will make you spend hours learning the  mojo on u tube and steam .  The game that keeps giving !  MIUS FRONT !   Your  leadership awaits .  
It's a dream !

review:
Hands down the most interesting tactical simulator to date. Well supported by the devs who relentlessly turn out new content and bugfixes all the time. Might seem a bit overwhelming at first, but watch some tutorials on youtube and dive in! The game is easy enough to play once you know the basics, but even after all this time, I still discover new things.
This is a must play for any strategy fan!

author: {'steamid': '76561198021877046', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1260, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 412, 'last_played': 1710957379}
review: With only six hours of gameplay at the time of my writing this review, I can say with confidence that after completing my first campaign, this game is nothing short of AMAZING. I have played many RTS/4X/Grand Strategy games before, however, the realism of this simulator is simply incredible. Just after playing these six hours through one campaign I am convinced that I will own every DLC that comes out for this game. Everything from infantry advancing under smoke cover, tanks exchanging blows from across the battlefield, and the roar of machine guns shredding anything in their path are just a few of the many exciting things that Graviteam Tactics: Mius-Front has to offer. If you are a fan of historical accuracy and all things World War Two then this may be the game for you! My only recommendation is to look up a couple tutorials online before starting so you do not become overwhelmed by the complexity of this game. If you would rather pass on the tutorials, just have patience and enough clicking around in game will get you all of the general knowledge you will need to be successful on the battlefield. Thanks Graviteam for the fantastic experience and I hope this helps anyone who is on the fence about buying this game feel more confident in their purchase!

author: {'steamid': '76561198045735588', 'num_games_owned': 594, 'num_reviews': 463, 'playtime_forever': 4784, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2406, 'last_played': 1699738040}
review:
Znacznie usprawniony względem Operation Star, zdecydowanie więcej opcji które pozwalaja na swobodniejszą rozgrywkę. Skala operacji wyraźnie powiększona, teraz na polu bitwy mogą ścierać się setki żołnierzy i do kilkudziesięciu czołgów co niestety przekłada się na średnią optymalizację przy największych starciach i to na każdym sprzęcie. 
Na szczęście kampanie możemy rozgrywać w starym stylu dowodząc małymi oddziałami wielkośći plutonów lub jeśli wolimy bardzie widowiskowe walki, to mamy do wyboru drugą opcję w której znajduje się po kilka plutonów w jednym oddziale a co za tym idzie na mapie operacji możemy poruszać się swobodniej i z większym marginesem błędu.
Pozycję polecam każdemu fanowi strategii, gdyż nawet jeśli nie jest to typowy RTS co należy zaznaczyć, to mechnika walki, dowodzenia, poziomu AI i realizmu stoją na naprawdę wysokim poziomie a wszystko to z bardzo ładną grafiką pojazdów i żołnierzy oraz świetnymi odgłosami walk. Potyczki nocą zasługują na oddzielną pochwałe, pociski smugowe, dym unoszący się ze spalonych pojazdów wysoko nad polem bitwy a takich smaczków jest tu pełno.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002681973', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 5762, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 985, 'last_played': 1710921224}
review: Another Graviteam Tactics gem. With scenarions from both offensive and defensive postures of the two major factions during the ostfront generation war. These are engagements in everything from small towns to sweeping areas covered by entire divisions. While the UI can still be quite difficult for newer players I would encourage you put the time in to learn it. I'd imagine 4 hours for a fairly quick learner before you can have smooth deployments. You will learn the hard way if you fuck up. Kick the training wheels off and make sure the realism factor is 110%. Learn from your mistakes, reform, and try again. This is as close as your going to get working an entire battalion with both on and off-map support weapons and personnel. Take your time and good luck.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007990766', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 115, 'playtime_forever': 92, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 32, 'last_played': 1596722059}
review: Любителям серьезных тактико-стратегических игр - если продеретесь через зубодробительное обучение - получите несказанное удовольствие от игры. Подобных по глубине проработки так сразу и не вспомню. Ознакомился и играл на пиратке. Теперь прикупил вместе с пачкой дополнений. Обязательно вернусь, только наберусь духа еще раз пройти обучение :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197963845815', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 92167, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 51483, 'last_played': 1703184923}
review:
So much love has been poured into this gem, that it's a must have for anyone who like this genre of games. 

It can be a little difficult at first if you're completely new and need learn all the game mechanics,  but don't let that discourage you. Learning the game mechanics while trying not to get your behind kicked by the AI, can be an adventure in itself.

Others have went into great detail about the pros and cons and the mechanics of the game wich i agree with so i'll leave that be. I just want to add that you will never feel that your money is wasted, you get countless hours of wargaming (the best) and two battles are never the same.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976352100', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1718, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1097, 'last_played': 1665711473}
review:
With a title like “Graviteam Tactics” I imagined a futuristic shooter in a gravity-free environment.  Instead it’s a great modern era RTS set around Kharkov in 1942-43.  As some other reviews warn, this is not a casual RTS.  No base building, and no units to buy.  Company of Heroes this is not, and you should avoid Graviteam Tactics if that or Men of War is your thing.  

The maps are not the typical RTS strain of hyper-compressed terrain to keep you going, rather these are realistic maps of the actual RL terrain, complete with wide open spaces measured in kilometers, hills, gullies, etc.  All that space is going to impact your tactics when you deal with an enemy’s long-range weapons as your digital squaddies hump their ruck across those wide open spaces.  

No doubt there are plenty of vehicles in Graviteam Tactics, but the battles depicted here are those fought by the leg infantry, not the pointy end of the armored-mechanized blitzkrieg-ing spear.   To me, this is the most challenging and interesting part of the game.  The learning curve is steep, and the  manual and tutorials are too poor to teach you much, but you’ll find much more help/examples of play on YouTube.  At a dozen hours I am still tinkering and trying to figure things out, and having fun doing it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012399725', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 64284, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 177, 'playtime_at_review': 14890, 'last_played': 1712286647}
review:
とてもリアルな連隊～小隊規模の戦闘を再現できるゲームというよりはシミュレーターといった趣です。設定によりますがスペックが許すならおおよそ1000人vs1000人程度までいけます。他の人が書いている通りかなり難しいです。迂遠に感じるかもしれませんがチュートリアルを全てやって、それでもわからない所が出てくるので適宜マニュアルを読むのがゲームのシステムを理解する早道だと思います。マニュアルなどに乗ってない索敵時や敵前を横切る時の最適な行軍体形。対戦車砲のよい使い方などはユーザーズガイドで少し前にロシア人の方が英語に翻訳してくれたのでちょっと前の手探りの状態よりは遥かにやりやすくなってます。

あとアップデートが結構頻繁にされますが、そのたびに戦闘モードのセーブがリセットされるのでできるだけ戦闘は終わらせた方がいいです。

author: {'steamid': '76561198104554250', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 22991, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7037, 'last_played': 1708499095}
review: This game and its sister game tank warfare tusnia are some of the best rts games on the market, They do have  a difficult learning curve but its well worth the time and effort. The game comes with like 4 individual operations but All the operations are replayable and you won't get the same battle twice. plus you can play as both sides on each operation.  The ai is very  sneaky it'll flank, it'll ambush, Ive been fu**ed up by the ai in this game even after playing it and its predecessor operation star for a long time it still gets me every now and then. In some aspects its slow but in others it can be a d*ck. it does put up a really good fight and doesnt stick to the same tactics like most rts games. Also the amount of little details that the developers put into this game is remarkable. for instance when a tank fires a few times smoke will start to billow out of hatches. If a tank gets tracked the crew will get out (if its safe) and repair it with a sledge hammer. small things like that matter i mean you got a full blown battle going on. and you got a crew trying to fix their tank to get mobile again. All of the units and maps are historical too. they really did a great job with this game i hope to see many more in the future.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070895634', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 7754, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 33, 'playtime_at_review': 2363, 'last_played': 1712340266}
review:
This game is brutal, unforgiving and not for the uninitiated, If your accustomed to games like CoH, or MoW than this game may not be for you, The learning curve is steep and the tutorial is poor but if you are an avid Strategy gamer than this game is your baby.  There are two phases of operations in this game, Operations Phase were you move Units at the Platoon Level along the map into strategic positions and plan assaults, And the Tactical Phase where you make you Assault of the Line or Defense of your positions. what this game succeeds in is making the Most Realistic Military Simulator i have ever played. You Control any where from the squad/ Platoon level and the all the Way to Battalions or regimental level. You control supplies, Reserves, as well as deciding the overall positions of the various units (and they are various, 100's of vehicles and guns in game), You also must try and rotate units into and out of the fighting when available or their morale will deteriorate the more fighting and loses they take. Line of sight is everything in this game, your AT guns can't kill what they can't see, Off map Arty needs observers who must be close enough to the front to see what they are hitting but far enough to not be killed in the engagement. Infantry are useless against armor, but may be able to take a tank out of action by crippling its tread with a Grenade. even the Angle of impact affects weapon damage, shells can ricochet and go else where or a single shot can kill an entire crew. the AI is smart and adaptive to your strategies and no too skirmishes will ever be the same. You use realistic Intelligence, your commanders tell you they knocked out 4 tanks but in reality they really killed one but the other three were damaged and may have lost crew but are still very much operational. Will you launch an infantry assault on fortified and dug in troops with a Battalion of infantry or will you send tanks in just a head and send in an Assault company with flamethrowers to dislodge the opposition. Will you fire a small arty barrage of 3 rounds per gun or expend an Entire batteries ammunition on an enemy position before you advance. the longer your troops stay in position the more they dig in, starting with foxholes, then moving into entire trench networks and even minefields. All your orders are relayed in real time from HQ, platoon that's cut off from the company may not get the orders relayed to them unless the Cable is still active, you'll watch soldiers with cable spools on their back run from CP to CP to gain radio contact. The AI will take cover and throw smoke and engage at will or Ambush if you so order them too. But once the fighting starts, just as in real life, micromanaging can become a chore and if you issue conflicting orders they will not be issue properly, or if you issue an order and then change it the unit may refuse the order entirely.if you order a suicidal frontal charge for a single platoon that's been battered and beat for days in game they may not be as likely as the fresh company that just got put on the front-line to make that assault. the Battles go on for days in game, the Skirmishes can go from 30 mins to 2 hrs in real time, this game is heavily reliant on patience and planning. if you poorly position troops you'll suffer heavy loses, and once units are lost they can not be rebuilt, at the start of an operation your given a Division or Brigade sized force that you are Solely in charge of, a Finite number from start to finish to make you decide how to go about it. I hope this review is helpful, this games learning curve is mighty steep and many lessons are learned by trial and error but i will say this strategy game has made me lose interest in most other strategy games of today because of the depth and detail taken by the developers.

EDIT: Yes the game after a few years since this review is still $35 usd, But i still stand by that this game is 100% worth the price of it AND all of it's DLC. the dev's continue to update the game and are still even releasing DLC, there's 100's of hours of game play with all of the DLC. Another thing i forgot to mention with this game is it is more macro managing then most other games in this genre. You tell the soldiers to move, and the parameters in the command with which you want to be followed and they follow through with the command as best as they see fit.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974770053', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 190, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 190, 'last_played': 1542517266}

author: {'steamid': '76561197973429614', 'num_games_owned': 1151, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 6463, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1991, 'last_played': 1705090566}
review:
Graviteam games (Mius Front, Tank Warfare: Tunisia 1943 and their predecessors) are games like no other on the market. It has some similarities with Combat Mission and even Close Combat series, but both have differences in mechanics and can't match the depth of MF how tactical battles and operations and modeled. Mius Front is a hard core historical battlefield simulator, where command, morale, weapon effects and rate of fire, armor, movement and many other details are modeled in such depth that it will continue to amaze you the more you play it.

Audiovisually Mius front is very pleasing. And when you start to learn and more like understand the underlying mechanics, it also becomes pretty natural to play. Here also is the biggest caveat of the game. Especially at first, the UI looks like a mess and it feels like it is constantly trying to hide information from you. And when the battle starts. you are soon overwhelmed when you try to keep everything together and still it seems that the troops don't do what you want. Frustration grows as does your casualties and quite basic game manual just gives you more questions how everything really works.

If you just hang on and preferably replay some small battle few times and try different approaches and search Steam and dev forums for the questions you have, game definitely starts to grow on you. There is the point when you finally understand how to approach it, that is without micromanagement, and how the underlying simulation works, and then also Mius Front starts to shine. Learning curve is steep and if you are expecting a lighter and more straight forward RTS, this game will just fill your backlog after few hours. You need time and patience with this one.

And even after you feel you start to master the game, it still may infuriate you at times. Sometimes the AI, which is at the core of the game even on the player side, feels like it is betraying you and your plan. And in many cases it is impossible to know if it is just a bad AI behaviour or something that even should happen in that particular situation. I know that in many cases it is the latter and player just makes a bad decision which troops can't effectively execute, but it is difficult to tell the difference without knowing all the algorithms and their relation to each other within the simulation engine. Again, much of the information game uses is hidden from the player or difficult to interpret from the UI. Game can feel extremely frustrating even after dozens of hours of gameplay.

But when everything clicks, and thankfully it does very often, Mius Front feels awesome and rewards the player. When the fight starts and tracers starts to fly in the dark, there is no other game that captures the feel of the battlefield in similar way. When you see your perfectly placed anti tank guns knocking out several advancing tanks, and thus slowing enemy assault to halt, you almost start to cheer for your virtual crews. If you have military backround or knowledge of company-level tactics, you can use that knowledge for inital troop placement and conducting effective attacks or counterattacks. 

Last but not least positive aspect of these games are the devs themselves. Mius Front, like its predecessors, has really long  lifecycle. Devs actively release patches and improve the games for years on and they are also active in the Steam forums with answering player questions, giving advice and listening ideas and bug reports. DLCs are all of top quality with historically correct troops and all the maps are created using real map data, both of which give emphasis to the simulation nature of the game. Every single one of the DLCs are worth the price and still, even the base game has tons of content. You can also spice up the game with few mostly visual mods.

Mius Front is without a doubt a game that is a work of passion of small, but talented team. It definitely isn't suited for everyone, is hard to master, can be confusing and makes sometimes you swear like a sailor when it falls apart in front of you, but it is one of the most rewarding games out there for a certain type of player. If you feel you have the patience to learn it, you won't be dissapointed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198157079293', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 2305, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1170, 'last_played': 1687645362}
review: Infantry have no anti-tank weapons is not real. Anti-tank  grenades, mines, even a glass bottle filled with gasoline will do certain damage to tanks. In this game, a single tank can rush into the positions hold by a infantry regiment, shooting and killing and surviving forever.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966371717', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 21136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12007, 'last_played': 1695870466}
review:
Great niche title!
Pros:
-Very detailed, perhapse best on the consumer market simulation of various physics systems for vehicles, projectiles, fragmentation and damage models.
-Interesting take on the battalion level tactics genre focusing on a more hands off, slow and deliberate approach to orders that tries to stop cheat type behaviour by the player often seen is this genre.
-Dynamic campaigns, fight over the same area again and see the craters and bodies from the previous battle!
-Very detailed and painstakingly researched hand crafted maps, which you can then deform and destroy!
-Historically accurate force composistions.
-Nice graphically effects (for the genre), hit a tank in it's fuel tank and watch as it leaves a trail of fire behind it, blow the wheels off an apc and see shrapnel rip into everything in a group of infantry.
-Very active development with constant improvements and free patches (which sometimes have new vehicles!), active dev involvement in the forum to answer questions.
-Great commitment to detail.
-Lots of dlc for lessor known WW2 eastern front battles.

Cons
-Can have a rough learning curve and be overwhelming for new players, especially if you haven't played other games like it but stick with it, read the manual and it will reward your effort.
-Can overload even the best computer in the largest battles.
-Needs a time commitment to play the campaign, a single battle can run for 2 hours (can be set shorter 30min, 1hour but it rushes the AI tactics) and there will be multiple battles per turn in a campaign that could run for more than 10 turns. (there are quick battle options and an editor but most work goes into the campaign).
-Made by non-English speakers so some of the text can be odd but everything is understandable.
-No Multiplayer, would be great but still in the unknown future.
-Scenerio type missions arn't supported so you can't make or play carefully handcrafted mission like other games in the genre (heavy focus on the dynamic campaign but does have a quick dynmaic mission maker and a battle editor to make your own dynamic missions.)

100% recomend for fans of the genre, WW2 buffs or people who love detailed damage models and simulation.
Fans of  WW2 desert warfare should check TankWarfare tunisia 1943 which is a "seperate but the same" game set in 1943 Tunisia, it gets all the same patches as this one..

author: {'steamid': '76561198173686814', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 9344, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5946, 'last_played': 1705158171}
review: Превосходная игра, одна из лучших в своем жанре. Уникальная детализация поля боя, максимально достоверная картина боя второй мировой. как жаль что такие отличные раззработчи с таким шикарным проектом зарабатывают так мало денег.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985889829', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 10415, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8857, 'last_played': 1604005098}
review:
Graviteam Tactics: Mius-Front is a realism-driven RTS centered on a selection of operations on the eastern front in World War 2. the game itself is split between two engines, a turn based operational map, and a real time battle simulator. This is not unlike the Total War franchise's setup, though the operational phase is much smaller scale and lacks any base management, serving only to manage troop movement and organization. 

Pros:
-Graphically, this is perhaps the best looking hardcore wargame in existence. While certainly not up to modern AAA gaming standards, Mius Front features full 3D graphics and a clean menu layout in a genre that... isn't exactly known for putting much thought or effort in aesthetics. Tracers stream across the battlefield, tanks explode in dramatic fashion, artillery shells and vehicles kick up great plumes of smoke, and the scars of war--wrecks, shell holes and bodies of the fallen, are retained from battle to battle.  In most wargames, you're lucky to get more than generic Nato tokens for for unit counters, and some franchises haven't updated their UIs in a decade or more. To be honest, I've been so spoiled by the graphics in Mius Front that I honestly have trouble going back to some of these other games.

-The attention to detail and realism is immense. wepon loadouts are handled down to the man and/or vehicle, and utilize the full variety of historically accurate ammunition types. The maps are immaculate. you can pull up google maps and punch in a battlefield, and, barring areas of urban expansion, the roads, towns, rivers, mountains and gullies, and even many forests can still be seen 1-to-1 in game. It helps that the devs, being Ukrainian, have relatively easy access to the featured battlefields and are known to visit them in-person. One particular highlight for me is their emphasis on lines of communication, an aspect typically overlooked or heavily abstracted in similar games. Formations keep in contact through flares, phones and radios, and keeping these chains of communication intact is essential for maintaining morale, firing capabilities, and the ability to issue orders. It's rather impressive to watch your communications squads running through the thick of battle, desperately laying telephone wire in an attempt to reestablish contact with their superiors. This was never really something I had considered before while wargaming, and it gave me a surprising new perspective on combat.

Cons:
I have many minor gripes with this game, so I'll leave those out here (they are, after all, minor), and focus on what I see are two underlying issues with Mius Front as is:

-Mius Front is very bad at explaining itself. while the game comes with manuals, tutorials and tool tips, they are often rather vague or poorly worded. I had to learn a lot of fundamentals through no small amount of trial and error, and there are still quite a few mechanics that I'm rather fuzzy on. Artillery mechanics in particular can be be a sticking point for  newcomers-- it's rarely clear whether the battery's refusal to fire is one of line of sight, lack of a comms link, the ai just throwing a fit (more on that later), or who knows what else.  Part of this is probably due to the language barrier with being a Ukranian team and all, but that doesn't really change the result. Expect to be confused, and be willing to spend some time getting to know the various commands, alerts and information panels.

-This aspect is a little hard to summarize, but it's basically that the level of abstraction is less than your actual level of control.  Mius front generally only allows for broad orders at the squad level-- the actions of individual squadsmen are left almost entirely up to the AI. you can't, for instance, force a unit to fire exclusively on a particular enemy,  or decide squad positions within a given house. Most of the time, this isn't an issue, and adds to the 'realism' of being a CO on a historic battlefield. however, there are an seemingly endless moments of frustration-- for instance, watching your squad mg plant himself squarely behind a large tree that blocks his prime firing line,  or having your tank spin around and expose its vulnerable side armor, or watching your anti tank gun team, with enemy tanks barreling towards them, apparently decide to break for tea  and refuse to fire until it's too late and your position is being overrun. now, there are ways to deal  most of these issues in game, but they're often clunky or a drain on your command capabilities, and half the time I can't even catch the issue until the damage has already been done.

In spite of these issues, I still find Mius Front to be immensely enjoyable,  and would consider it to be one of my favorites  in the genre, only really comparable to the Steel Panthers franchise.  

One final note: the main dev is quite active on the steam forums with answering questions and the like on the forums here. Which is pretty awesome, except.... the man's got sass. Don't expect a placating,  PR-styled response if you have a question or complaint. At the very least, he's not afraid to tell you you're flat-out wrong and your idea would never happen. He obviously has a real commitment to his vision for this game, and... I have a huge amount of respect for that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198231029056', 'num_games_owned': 136, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 7578, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 663, 'last_played': 1707178131}
review:
This is a very good RTS. As people have said, it's hard, but that's where the game comes into it's own. You must use your environment to gain an advantage, and deploy your forces in a thoughtful way. Your troops will do all the nitty gritty.

Not for the weak hearted. Mistakes sometimes make this a strange, emotional viewing of a tragic bloodbath. Successes may have you excitedly palming your screen in a vain attempt at high fiving your squad leaders.

8/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014180469', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 28133, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12263, 'last_played': 1705077788}
review:
This game is a true gem among the RTS titles, by far the most accurate simulation of WW2 combat on the market today.
However it is important buyers know that this game can be confusing at times because of the detailed simulation of WW2 combat, tanks are designed with accurate armor thickness, gun and shell penetration statistics and limited visibility of the crew to the outside world. You give orders to your men however you need to make sure there are lines of communication linking your troops to the leading commander, each unit has it's own AI that's self sufficient and realistic, unlike Total war titles these units don't require constant babysitting. Troops that come under artillery fire during an engagement might run for cover in shell holes or trenches to escape the shrapnel flying through the air.
For the casual RTS players it can be frustrating at first to find out tanks can get bogged down in thick mud before they even get to combat but that's what happened historically, or how the hell you fight a WW2 engagement in the first place, but the end result is amazing as countless people demonstrate with pictures of their experiences in the screenshot thread on the steam forums.

author: {'steamid': '76561198202451143', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1072, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 976, 'last_played': 1571523607}
review:
When It All Comes Together                                                                                                          

I suppose I could write, “when it all falls apart,” however, I will leave that for another review.

Despite the anomalies and nuances in Mius Front, there are moments I really admire in this game.

There is a lot going on at times under the hood of Mius Front we often think has little to do with AI, yet in fact, the AI is often taken for granted in this game and we often misappropriate its role in the game mechanic. In many cases company level platoons which are static will provide support fire when you begin to execute associated tactics. After all, this is the reason why the game is called Graviteam “Tactics.” Often times I think we deserve more control, and in doing so, miss the core fundamental features underlying the game and often times mess things up. There are literally hundreds of move combinations and one can never be sure how they actually pan out.

These fundamental factors in terms of game mechanics are observed in remarkable ways. 

Example: I plan an assault on a Soviet entrenched position in open ground. I start from cover in a tree line about 500 meters away. I have four platoons. Platoons one, two and three will conduct the assault as a left flanking maneuver with platoon four anchoring my right flank in cover. The fourth platoon on the right flank, without instruction, will begin to lay down smoke and suppressing fire as my assault group leaves the form up position in attack formation. I issue no command to the fourth platoon but surprised by the “AI” in action. Therefore, I run with it. As I leap frog my assault platoons (in short 50-meter spurts) in over-watch style, it is amazing to watch the combined arms experience when it all comes together. 

The AI often does a better job than me and yet it is always unpredictable.

Recon notes my left flank is clear. Further on down the tree line, on the right, I have several platoons entrenched in defensive positions with small anti-tank guns and a few light artillery pieces. They also support the fight unexpectedly once the enemy positions become exposed by the advancing assault platoons. There is a whole company involved here due to “AI” communications, yet I have only issued commands to three platoons. No need to micro-manage here as I watch the other platoons come together dynamically and in never the same way twice. 

Subsequently, I can pan around and watch the battle unfold from several perspectives. I trust the system. The Mius doctrine is not easy to embrace simply because we want more control. Not all games pan out this way but when it all comes together I am left with a deeply satisfying wargame experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001757257', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 28108, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 49, 'playtime_at_review': 2344, 'last_played': 1711986301}
review:
Steel Panthers -> Close Combat -> Combat Mission -> Graviteam Tactics: Mius Front.
Mius-Front is the best WW2 RTS game I have ever played. It captures the atmosphere and fighting of the Eastern such a epic way that theres no other contenders. Tank and gun models are great and full of details. Like when a KV1 tank was hit by 50mm at gun and the KV1 lost the drivers armor and you could see the driver inside the tank. 9/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000730236', 'num_games_owned': 1107, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 4517, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3826, 'last_played': 1634013791}
review:
[h1]Stick through the difficult learning curve and you will be rewarded with a unique gem of an RTS set in WW2![/h1]
[i]While a little difficult at first every battle I play of this game is a spectacle and show like none other.[/i]
Artillery crashing all over, tracers and men flying through the air, tanks crushing through the wire on the way to your front lines, and radio men trying not to get shot running wire to the front. 

The menus and UI are a little confusing, but provide superior control and depth once you get the hang of them. 
Graphics are a little dated but provide massive scale and effects that really put you into the battle. 
Audio is second to none (Albiet I am using the sound mod from the steam forums). 
There are multiple "operations" you play that are multiple part large scale battles, or a battle editor to make your own. 
The new xpac Black Snow is fantastic and reminds me of the movie "Talvisota". A lot of good atmposphere is you pay attention to the details. 

Only negative is the very difficult learning curve. 
They have improved the turtorial, and there are some good video turtorials to watch, other than that it's very hard.

The dev team is constantly updating the games and they have added some really good features recently which is always nice to see.

I would reccomend this game to any RTS fan and to anyone interested in a complete ww2 battle simulator.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021670287', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 19880, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1, 'playtime_at_review': 4017, 'last_played': 1712082293}
review:
Le meileur jeu opérationnel et tactique du marché et de loin. Bien au dessus de la série Combat mission. Des cartes immenses, du réalisme et que dire de l'immersion...On s'y croirait. On peut aussi bien y voir un russe jeter un coktail Molotov dans un trou et les soldats ennemi prendre feu qu'assister à une attaque massive d'IL 2 sur une colonne de char à la roquette, bataille de nuit à la fusée éclairante. Peut-être un peu difficile de prise en main au début, mais le jeu en vaut la chandelle. Je suis le jeu depuis le tout début avec "Achtung Panzer" et j'ai tous les modules Tunisie et Russie. Le suivi des concepteurs est constant et les MAj nombreuses et efficaces sur l'amélioration du Jeu. De nouvelles batailles sortent régulièrement et à chaque fois des heures de jeu possible. Vraiment bravo à l'équipe. 
En un mot: Foncez!

author: {'steamid': '76561197975522760', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 27799, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13117, 'last_played': 1594944687}
review: The best WW2 strategy-simulation I've ever had the pleasure of playing. The learning curve is absolutely overwhelming, from learning to decipher the order of battle screens, assigning support weapons to the appropriate platoons, properly  using artillery units, to  attempting to locate and destroy entrenched enemy positions waiting to ambush your troops, you will send many men to their deaths due to your own ineptitude and it is glorious.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989229737', 'num_games_owned': 736, 'num_reviews': 286, 'playtime_forever': 9373, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9373, 'last_played': 1630887729}
review:
The latest UI update is terrible. Buttons are at least twice the size and now shades of grey and black. Everything blends in and it's very difficult to get information at a glance. 

With icons so big even medium operations can no longer show all units.  An arrow is often needed to toggle which units can be seen. Back when all units were seen, if one started going red it was a indicator it's pinned down, low on ammo, fatigued, or otherwise in trouble. It called my attention to things I could potentially miss watching the battle. Now with unit icons hidden I miss valuable information hidden by the interface.

With everything to large and stacked high UI takes almost a quarter of the bottom part of the screen. not to mention the wider panels on the side taking even more screen real estate away.

The Previous UI was soo good idk how they got to this awful mess. I hope it's changed back soon because the new UI is unplayable

author: {'steamid': '76561197970752601', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 14962, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3614, 'last_played': 1710442521}
review:
Thought I would review this game because it really is a hidden Gem. I've been a huge fan of the Scourge of war series by matrix game and I can't help but relate this game to it. Instead of 18th century warfare, which is my first love, this is a nice breath of fresh air. 

To me, I prefer realism above all else. I know a lot of people cannot stand the tedious micromanagment that comes with that, but for the grogs out there, this is where you will find this game to shine the most. It took me about 3-4 hours of playtime to get a grasp of the mechanics for this game, not long at all compared to some other stratagy games I have played in the past. It's not that hard as some in the reviews might have you believe. The best part is that learning the game is half the fun. 

The graphics are beautiful and FX are beautiful! Maybe not AAA quality but I've never seen damage models and ballistics so accuratlly potrayed. The attention to detail is somthing to behold and by far the best I've ever seen in any game I've ever played. Hats off to the devs. There is somthing about seeing hundreds of men charge up a hill to take your pefectly planned position. Cross fields of fire with machine gun nests, and then seeing the enemy drop to the ground shaking with fear not being able to move. Then you call in the mortars and after a few minutes they stand up throw down their weopons and surrender. 

The AI is great! Probably the best by i've seen with similar type games. Still some hiccups here and there but will provide hundreds of hours of entertainment. I've found the AI to be far less predictable at the tactical level than most other games i've played. 

The UI is clunky, but functional and once you learn it you will learn to love it. I'm happy I found this game, I really cannot believe it took me so long to come across it. Will be buying more games from graviteam tactics. 

9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198023130923', 'num_games_owned': 300, 'num_reviews': 118, 'playtime_forever': 1222, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 38, 'last_played': 1702630245}
review:
I give this a thumbs up even if I refunded it :P.. I quickly came to the conclusion that this is HARD CORE strategy for the very edge of hard core battalion level strategy fans! We are talking about a 90 degrees learning curve here but I'm sure this is a marvelous simulator when mastered.. Not for impatient players or people who doesn't want 100% realism on behalf of playability. I'm impressed by the work and research the devs have put into this but gameplay was overwhelmingy complex for me.

Edit: I re-bought the game after watching several youtube vids and now after a while of learning and playing my review remain possitive. Alltho the ai is extremely unrealistic in my opinion. for example infantry move out of cover in to open ground and obviously expose themselves without given any orders to do so. I know the game is trying to simulate a realistic command system and the confusion of combat but running out of cover in the direction of the enemy without assulting or tactically moving is simply stupid.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037682069', 'num_games_owned': 111, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 9984, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1943, 'last_played': 1707024591}
review:
Bonjour ,
je suis un fan invétéré de jeux de tactique stratégie ;les totale war ,les wargames ;les compagny of heros ;
les Scourge of War ,les théatre of war .
tous ont de très bonne références .
Mais j'admet que ces créateurs Ukrénien ont développé un sens puriste du jeux stratégique tactique historique .
Poussé à l'excelence , la pirotechnique ,les dommages ,la balistique à des détails et précision historique encore jamais exploité jusqu'ici .
Cest un spéctacle admirable , comparable à un documentaire sur le terrain , par des journalistes de guerre ,que de participer 
à des bataille historiques aveec les contrainte de l'époque .
Même si , la préparation semble laborieuse , le résultat est des plus surprenant .
L'intelligence artificielle démontre qu'elle n'est pas en reste d'efficacité .
Merci à l'atelier de ces créateurs invésti .
c'est de loint l'un des meilleurs jeux de guerre que j'ai introduit dans ma collection .

author: {'steamid': '76561198023507159', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 117, 'playtime_forever': 4433, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2617, 'last_played': 1640962827}
review: The game has a horrible tutorial, but your learning curve can be mitigated by YouTube searches and simple trial and error.  At first the fog of war can be totally obfuscated by the complete and utter confusion of what's going on, but I personally LOVE this game and find this to be a step up in the series.

author: {'steamid': '76561198138877701', 'num_games_owned': 503, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 4006, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2638, 'last_played': 1652490154}
review:
Without getting into a huge amount of detail, the game has its problems, but is great. Expect to macro-manage instead of micro-manage. This game falls into a [i] very [/i] niche category of games; make sure you know what it is before you buy it.
 
The things units do will frustrate you. Sometimes a soldier will throw 4 grenades at an enemy soldier 10 meters in front of him, in plain view, instead of shooting him with his SMG, and proceed to get gunned down by the soldier he was trying to kill. Or a tank will roll up behind an AT gun and just will not fire, no matter what. Sometimes I wish there was a [i] Men Of War [/i] style "direct control" in this game.

Infantry combat is fairly lackluster and can't be micro-managed no matter how hard you try. The audio isn't very good and the animations are bad. It's up to RNG and numbers most of the time to determine who wins a skirmish.

In my opinion, tank combat is where this game shines. Models are beautiful and realistic. Armor values are true to the real life tanks and so are the penetration values, type of shells, ballistics and everything else. 

I mostly play in the custom battles to mess around, and have tried the campaigns only a few times, which are very difficult.
